title: Elections to the European Parliament:  Go-to-Vote!
text: The European Parliament is running a campaign to help increase voter engagement in the upcoming European elections, which will take place on 23-26 May. Elections are the one moment when each and every one of us has the opportunity to cast our vote and choose our future.  Watch  video http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/elections-press-kit/5/choose-your-future   Read more And while we can’t solve today’s global challenges individually or even on a national level, together in Europe we can lead the way. This is what makes European elections all the more important. And this is why we need your help. Below you will find the European Parliament’s “Choose your future” campaign film. It features documentary footage of newborns around Europe coming to the world; an emotional moment that comes with a great sense of responsibility for the future well-being of the new life. The children in this film will inherit the decisions we take today. epfacebook.eu/chooseyourfuture + epyoutube.eu/chooseyourfuture

title: Digitalisation of aircraft maintenance with Clean Sky 2’s AIRMES project
text: NULL

title: Full support for Clean Sky 2!
text: The Clean Sky 2 event ‘European aeronautics research at its best: what next in Horizon Europe?’ got off to a flying start today in Brussels. The event was opened by Clean Sky’s new Executive Director Axel Krein, who took the opportunity to highlight the achievements of Clean Sky to date and look ahead to how the technologies developed can have the best possible impact on the greener aviation of the future. A lively panel discussion was held with a variety of speakers representing the different sectors playing a crucial role in Clean Sky: Clara de la Torre, Director for Transport, DG RTD, European Commission; Grazia Vittadini, Chief Technology Officer, Airbus; Lucian Puiu Georgescu, Secretary of State for Science and Innovation, Romania; Valeria Fascione, Regional Minister for Innovation of Campania region; and Henri Werij, Dean, Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, TU Delft University. A short ceremony then took place to thank the former Chair of the Governing Board Ric Parker and Vice Chair Bruno Stoufflet, as well as interim Executive Director of Clean Sky Tiit Jürimäe. Their contribution to the achievements of the programme to date was acknowledged and appreciated. The day came to a close with a range of insights into the move from Clean Sky 2 to Clean Sky 3 from Monika Hohlmeier MEP; Violeta Bulc, European Commissioner for Mobility and Transport; and Stéphane Cueille, Chair of the Clean Sky Governing Board. Check out photos on our event page and stay tuned on our social media (LinkedIn and Twitter: follow the hashtag #CS2Impact) for Day 2 of the event which will look in detail at the achievements so far of Clean Sky 2’s technology platforms.

title: Bigger engines, bigger challenges. Clean Sky’s ASPIRE resolves them
text: For large passenger aircraft flying medium and long-haul routes, Ultra High Bypass Ratio (UHBR) Engines will power the majority of airliners over the next three decades. But at twice the size of today’s engines, their aerodynamic and aeroacoustic interaction with the rest of the aircraft presents many issues. Clean Sky’s ASPIRE project has brought the best of Europe’s research centres together to face those challenges. Read more.

title: Here’s the CA3TCH... Reducing risk with Clean Sky’s Digital Wind Tunnel
text: Innovative flight simulations using a ’digital wind tunnel’ developed under Clean Sky’s CA³TCH project bring pre-flight aerodynamic and aeroacoustic analyses to the next level. Read more.

title: Skyline 27 has arrived
text: Skyline 27 has arrived! In this Skyline issue, you will find a number of examples of how Clean Sky is currently delivering on our ambitious objectives of reducing CO2 emissions and noise levels in aircraft – read on to discover several key projects. Don’t miss the view from the European Commission’s Director-General for Research and Innovation Jean-Eric Paquet, focusing on what the future European aviation partnership might look like; and enjoy the opportunity to meet our new Executive Director Axel Krein. Read Skyline 27 here.

title: Clean Sky 2’s technical achievements in the spotlight
text: The Clean Sky 2 event ‘European aeronautics research at its best: what next in Horizon Europe?’ continued today with a focus on the technical achievements of the programme so far. The day was opened by Ron van Manen, Clean Sky 2 Programme Manager, who invited a wide range of speakers representing different Clean Sky partners to discuss their experiences: Peter Hecker, Chairman of the Clean Sky 2 Scientific Committee; Ingrid Kernstock, Member of the Clean Sky 2 States Representatives Group (Austria); Svjetlana Stekovic, EU Senior Research Officer from Linköping University; Bruno Stoufflet, Chief Technology Officer of Dassault Aviation; and Franco Tortarolo, R&D EU Programs and Academic & IP Executive of Avio Aero. A series of breakout sessions followed to look in more detail at each technology platform of the Clean Sky 2 programme. Coordinators of key projects for Large Passenger Aircraft, Fast Rotorcraft, Systems, Airframe, Engines and Regional Aircraft presented their achievements and results to date, highlighting the environmental benefits being brought about by their collaborative European research. Some key pieces of innovative hardware from the projects were also on display in the exhibit area. The breakout sessions were followed by a presentation on Eco-Design by Rainer Schweppe of Fraunhofer. The event ended on a reflective note with a look at the Technology Evaluator, Clean Sky’s tool for tracking progress and assessing impacts of its technologies by Kolja Kindler of DLR. Finally Axel Krein, Clean Sky’s Executive Director, closed the event with a look towards the future of aviation research in Europe. Thank you to everyone who attended our event! Check out photos on our event page and follow the hashtag #CS2Impact on social media (LinkedIn and Twitter) to revisit quotes and highlights of the two days!

title: A Clean Sky event in Castilla y Leon region
text: On 26 March 2019, an Info Day was organised in Valladolid, Castilla Y León, by the Regional Authorities, the Institute for Business Competitiveness of Castilla Y León (ICE) and the Centro Technologico de Miranda de Ebro (CTME). It was an event in the context of the MoU that was signed in 2017. The welcome address of this event was provided by Beatriz Casado Sáenz, Director of the Innovation and Entrepreneurship Department of the Castilla Y León, who stressed the efforts made by the regional authorities to support the aeronautical sector in the region. She highlighted the MoU that has been signed with Clean Sky JU and the current activities taken by the region towards the successful and effective implementation of this bilateral agreement. Read more here

title: Open Rotor wins 2019 Aviation Week Award for Commercial Aviation: Propulsion
text: The Open Rotor demonstrator, part of Clean Sky’s research efforts into greener engines, has been awarded Aviation Week’s Annual Laureate Award in the category Commercial Aviation: Propulsion. The award ceremony took place on 14 March in Washington DC. Designed to power upcoming generations of single-aisle commercial jets, the aim of the Open Rotor is to reduce fuel consumption and CO2 emissions by up to 30%, as well as noise. Its revolutionary architecture marks a significant break with current engine technology. Successful ground tests started in October 2017. The Open Rotor project is led by Safran, involving some 50 participants across Europe, and has a budget of €127 million, reflecting the excellence of Europe’s aeronautical R&D. This is the second time a Clean Sky project has been recognised at the Laureate Awards: the BLADE demonstrator won in the Commercial Aviation: Technology category in 2018. Read more.

title: Circular Economy: Composite Fuselage for regional aircraft takes shape
text: Weight and cost reduction in the manufacturing processes and health monitoring of an aircraft fuselage are key to the competitiveness of Europe’s regional aircraft industry. Clean Sky’s Composite Fuselage project is pushing forward the technological frontiers for European aviation. Read more.

title: Born again: Obsolete composites find a second life with RESET
text: Yesterday’s composite aircraft parts that are beyond serviceable standard have the chance to be reincarnated into new components for the airliners of the future, thanks to Clean Sky’s RESET project. Read more

title: NO-ICE ROTOR - a greener way to protect aircraft from icing
text: Our NO-ICE ROTOR project is pooling European research to come up with a greener way to protect aircraft from icing! The innovative lightweight heatable coating technology will be used for @LDO_Helicopters Tilt Rotor. Discover the results so far: @EU_H2020 Read more

title: Leveraging motor racing expertise for Clean Sky’s FastCan
text: For time-sensitive flights – particularly ’Golden Hour’ emergency medical evacuations and search and rescue operations – speed and agility are key. Airbus Helicopter’s RACER (Rapid And Cost-Effective Rotorcraft) demonstrator – one of two demonstrators to be built for Clean Sky’s ”Fast Rotorcraft” Innovative Aircraft Demonstrator Platform (IADP) – incorporates a whole host of inventive projects, including FastCan, which draws on motor racing knowhow to bring innovative design possibilities for the rotorcraft’s canopy. Read more.

title: Humans and robots team up for Clean Sky’s CRO-INSPECT
text: Increased use of composite materials in aircraft construction reduces weight and cuts fuel burn. That’s beneficial for the environment, but the structural complexity of composites necessitates new inspection regimes to verify quality during manufacture as well as for early detection of product degradation throughout the service lifespan. These inspections use ultrasonic techniques such as ’guided waves’, but are labour intensive. Clean Sky’s CRO-INSPECT project is developing a collaborative hybrid work cell whereby human diligence is complemented by robotic efficiency, paving the way for competitive industry processes in European aeronautics. Read more.

title: Clean Sky’s BALANCE: A smooth operator
text: A smoother engine nacelle means less drag, less fuel burn, and less emissions. Clean Sky’s BALANCE project is propelling the science of European nacelle design towards a seamless future. Read more.

title: Clean Sky’s T-WING: In conversation with CIRA
text: The design, manufacture and qualification of an innovative wing for the Next Generation of Civil Tilt-Rotor (NGCTR) is the remit of Clean Sky’s T-WING project which kicked off in February 2018. Coordinated by CIRA, the Italian Aerospace Research Centre, it is currently tackling a complex set of technical and environmental challenges with stringent targets. Just one year into its six year timeline, Luigi Di Palma, Coordinator of T-WING, and Marika Belardo, T-WING’s Chief Engineer, discuss the magnitude of the project and the path ahead. Read more.

title: UltraFan one step closer as Advanced Low Pressure System testing gets underway
text: A milestone has been reached for Rolls-Royce’s Advanced Low Pressure System (ALPS), part of Clean Sky’s Engine research efforts, with the first tests on a donor engine of all composite elements including fan blades, a fan case and annulus fillers. ALPS is a key step in bringing the UltraFan engine to life, which aims to deliver significant weight, noise and fuel burn reductions, making it 25% more efficient than a first-generation Trent engine. The ALPS engine parts are manufactured using state-of-the-art, fully automated construction methods at Rolls-Royce’s Composites Technology Facility, a Composites Centre of Excellence. Each fan blade is made robotically, building up around 500 layers of carbon fibre materials. Heat and pressure are then applied, and each blade is finished with a leading titanium edge, which offers extreme protection against foreign objects and bird strikes. The ALPS programme is a partnership between Rolls-Royce, Clean Sky, Innovate UK, the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, the Aerospace Technology Institute, ITP Aero and GKN. Read the Rolls-Royce press release.

title: Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking appoints Axel Krein as Executive Director
text: As of 1 February 2019, Axel Krein will take on the role of Executive Director of Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking, the European Public-Private Partnership for research in aeronautics, part of the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme. Mr. Krein has extensive experience in the aviation sector, having served as Senior Vice President Research & Technology at Airbus from 2007 to 2014, and most recently as Airbus Senior Vice President Cyber Security Program. Prior to these roles, he held the position of Airbus Senior Vice President Strategic Development. “Aeronautics in Europe is facing tremendous challenges ahead with regard to competition, the environment and also the impact of technology acceleration. We are at a crossroads and the coming years will determine the long-term success of the European aeronautics’ ecosystem. European Public-Private Partnerships such as Clean Sky are proven catalysers for innovative technology development and validation. I am pleased to join Clean Sky, which I am sure will continue to play a key role in decreasing the environmental footprint of future aircraft, while at the same time strengthening European competitiveness. I very much look forward to working together with European institutions and Clean Sky participants towards the achievement of these goals, both within the existing Clean Sky 2 programme and within Horizon Europe as from 2020.” Clean Sky 2 would like to thank Tiit Jürimäe, who served as interim Executive Director for the past two years, for his contribution to the development of the Joint Undertaking, particularly during its transition from Clean Sky 1 to Clean Sky 2.

title: Go with the flow: Clean Sky’s Hybrid Laminar Flow Control Demo
text: Controlling the flow of air around an aircraft by making that flow laminar can reduce fuel-burn and cut emissions up to 10%. Clean Sky’s Hybrid Laminar Flow Control (HLFC) demonstrator is putting the theory to the test. Read more.

title: The UHBR engine flight testing programme gathers momentum
text: The Ultra High Bypass Ratio (UHBR) engine demonstrator, UltraFan® for large aircraft is being developed within the framework of Clean Sky’s ENGINE ITD, and its flight testing is one of the major flagships of Clean Sky’s Large Passenger Aircraft (LPA) Innovative Aircraft Demonstration Platforms (IADP). The magnitude of work represents a major investment in innovative activities and the program has ambitious environmental targets that will deliver long term benefits for the future of European aviation. Read more

title: Clean Sky’s PIPS harnesses space tech for plane de-icing
text: As much as three percent of an aircraft’s fuel-burn is spent on deicing the engine intakes and the wings’ leading edges during flight. What if some of that energy could be saved? Clean Sky’s Passive Ice Protection System (PIPS) project uses technology originally developed for orbiting space satellites to bring fuel savings and reduced CO2 emissions for aviation. Read more.

title: European Aviation Environmental Report highlights need for innovative technologies
text: EASA’s 2019 European Aviation Environmental Report highlights that although the continuous growth in air traffic is beneficial for the European aviation sector, this comes hand in hand with greater emissions: therefore it is more important than ever to address the environmental impact of aviation. This is where Clean Sky comes in: a European-wide research partnership delivering innovative technologies to reduce CO2 & noise from aircraft. Discover our concrete results so far on pages 38-39 of the report. Read more.

title: Flying Beyond 2020: 4th European Aeronautics Conference
text: The 4th European Aeronautics Conference took place on 5 December in the European Parliament in Brussels, organised by Monika Hohlmeier MEP, Chair of the parliamentary Sky and Space Intergroup, and ASD Europe. The conference was opened by President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani, and featured high-level speakers including European Commissioners Maroš Šefčovič, Violeta Bulc, Elżbieta Bieńkowska and Günther Oettinger; MEPs Lieve Wierinck, Françoise Grossetête, Jacqueline Foster, Inés Ayala Sender and Marian-Jean Marinescu; and leading members of the European aeronautics industry involved in Clean Sky such as Airbus, Rolls-Royce, Dassault, Leonardo, Liebherr and GKN. Clean Sky’s newly-elected Governing Board Chairman Stéphane Cueille was also present to discuss how Europe can lead the way to sustainable and performance-based aviation. Speakers were in agreement about the value of Clean Sky and SESAR, with several highlighting the excellent collaborative research that is now delivering concrete results. Monika Hohlmeier emphasised: “Clean Sky and SESAR are brilliant projects: impressive European research programmes that are not known enough. Let the EU citizens know about them!” Read more about the event and download the 2018 Sky and Space Intergroup report here.

title: Apply now to Clean Sky Academy Award for the Best PhD Thesis in Applied Sciences and Engineering for Aeronautics
text: The Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking is pleased to announce the fourth edition of the Award to distinguish young scientists who have recently completed a PhD thesis in scientific fields related to Aeronautics. The Award aims to highlight outstanding achievements of scientists and researchers at the start of their careers. To apply, candidates are required to fill out and email the application form to phd-award@cleansky.eu. More information on the rules and procedures is available here

title: Save the date: Clean Sky 2 event 9-10 April 2019
text: The Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking is pleased to announce an event to present its promising first results and discuss future steps. ‘Clean Sky 2 Public-Private Partnership – European aeronautics research at its best: What next in Horizon Europe?’ will take place on 9-10 April 2019 in Brussels, Belgium. The first day will feature speakers from the European aeronautics industry, the European Parliament and European Commission, as well as research centres and academia, while the second day will take a closer look at the achievements of Clean Sky 2 so far. The event will take place at The Hotel, Boulevard de Waterloo 38, 1000 Brussels, Belgium. Participation is free but registration is mandatory. Registration for this event will open early February 2019.

title: Get under the skin of Clean Sky with HYPERDRILL
text: Airliners of the future could benefit from fuel savings of up to 10% by using Hybrid Laminar Flow Control, also known as ’hybrid laminarity’, a technique whereby part of the turbulent airflow around an aircraft is sucked through microperforations in its skin, creating a more stable aerodynamic flow. Clean Sky’s HYPERDRILL project is evolving the unique and ultraefficient production process for the manufacture of these skins, contributing to significant environmental benefits for European aviation. Read more

title: Propulsion: Safran Aircraft Engines
text: Under Europe’s Clean Sky research program, Safran ground-tested a full-scale counter-rotating open-rotor engine, showing substantial savings in fuel burn over the latest commercial turbofans and achieving significant reductions on noise over past open-rotor engines. This has earned them a place among the 2019 winners in Commercial Aviation, according to the Aviation Week Network's Laureate Awards. For more information, click here

title: European Court of Auditors issues clean opinion of Joint Undertakings
text: The European Court of Auditors has signed off the 2017 accounts of all the EU’s joint undertakings and issued clean opinions on the financial transactions for all except one. The auditors published the annual reports on the EU’s eight joint undertakings in research, as well as a summary of the audit results. Joint undertakings are the EU’s public-private partnerships with industry, research groups and Member States. They employ some 700 staff and play an important role in carrying out specific aspects of EU research policy. The total 2017 budget of the joint undertakings amounted to €2.1 billion, or about 2% of the total EU budget. Their industry and research partners provide in-kind contributions by implementing their operational activities and cash contributions to their administrative and operational costs. Read more: https://www.eca.europa.eu/en/Pages/NewsItem.aspx?nid=11063

title: Clean Sky discusses public-private model at Austrian Presidency event
text: Clean Sky took part in a high-level session on “Co-programming Partnerships” under Horizon Europe organised by the Austrian Presidency of the Council of EU and the European Commission in the framework of the International Conference ‘INDTECH 2018 - Innovative industries for smart growth’ which took place in Vienna on 29-31 October 2018. Bruno Mastantuono (Legal Manager & Strategy Advisor) presented a case study on Clean Sky 2 JU as the “Public-Private Partnership” in aviation R&I, with a focus on how the JU involves Member States in its governance and considerations on the use of the PPP/JU model to build a strategic roadmap to meet key EU priorities and foster synergies with national and regional programmes. The session was moderated by Jurgen Tiedje (Head of Unit at DG RTD of the European Commission) and included presentations by Max Lemke (Head of Unit at DG CONNECT of the European Commission) on Digitising European Industry innovation ecosystem and case studies from contractual PPPs. The event was attended by a large audience of delegates from EU institutions, Member States and national authorities, research organisations, academia and stakeholders. The presentations of the session are available here.

title: Read Skyline 26 now!
text: Skyline 26 has landed! This issue focuses on the progress achieved by Clean Sky 2 so far: check out the timeline of results and focus on key innovative projects. You can also read a wide variety of views on the future of research and innovation in European aeronautics from the European Parliament, the Romanian Presidency of the Council of the EU, the German Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy, and French research organisation ONERA. Finally, don’t miss the FAQ on how to apply to a Clean Sky 2 call, and news on our upcoming events! Read Skyline 26 here

title: Honeywell tests new technologies in flight for Clean Sky 2
text: Honeywell performed a flight test on their Falcon 900EX from/to Toulouse on 9 November to proceed with the acquisition of data for the development of new technologies under development within both Clean Sky 2 and SESAR 2020 programmes. Staff members from Honeywell, Airbus and the Clean Sky JU participated in this successful experiment. The test consisted of several approaches to Toulouse Blagnac Airport (France) for a total flight test duration of approximately 1 hour. This flight was part of a data collection campaign gathering over 70 hours of data throughout Europe. In Clean Sky 2, Honeywell works together with Airbus and Dassault Aviation on the development of a GP-AHRS (Hybridization GPS / Attitude and Heading Reference System, MEMS based). This prototype equipment was tested during this flight test with the aim to assess the position, velocity, and attitude capabilities in different configurations and to proceed with the acquisition of raw data. The flight testing will continue in Q1/Q2 2019 with an emphasis on the GNSS ionosphere irregularities in equatorial region. The work carried out by Honeywell in Clean Sky 2 aims to mature this technology with the ambition to introduce next generation products with broad applicability across aerospace applications that meet Clean Sky 2 High Level Objectives. This new technology, if successfully proven and matured until the end of Clean Sky 2, will allow for potential implementation beyond 2025 onto commercial air transport, business jet or rotary wing aircraft.

title: 9th Call for Proposals now open
text: The 9th Call for Proposals (CfP09) was launched on 6 November 2018 via the European Commission’s H2020 Participant Portal. CfP09 has a budget of €69.1 million for 55 topics including 4 thematic topics. The closing date is 6 February 2019. Registration is now open for our Info Days dedicated to CfP09 in Ankara on 15 November and Bordeaux on 20 November.

title: Clean Sky Governing Board elects new Chairman and Deputy Chairman
text: The Clean Sky Governing Board yesterday elected its new Chairman and Deputy Chairman: Stéphane Cueille, Senior Executive VP and Chief Technology Officer of Safran, takes on the role of Chairman, while Marco Protti, Head of Advanced Research of Leonardo Aircraft Division, will fill the Deputy role. Both were elected for a two-year term. Stéphane Cueille: “Clean Sky is entering a very important phase in delivering the innovative green technology Europe needs to remain aeronautics world leader. I am very happy to lead our Governing Board and all its Members towards the next European aviation partnership under the EU Horizon Europe programme”. Marco Protti: “I am strongly motivated to contribute to the management of the Governing Board, and support Stéphane Cueille to keep Clean Sky a model example of a European Public-Private Partnership in addressing societal challenges and engaging a European wide value chain”. Clean Sky would like to thank the outgoing Governing Board Chairman Ric Parker and his Vice- Chair Bruno Stoufflet for their excellent service and dedication to Clean Sky for the past four years.

title: Campania signs up 8 projects under the MoU with Clean Sky
text: The Campania Regional Minister for Innovation, Valeria Fascione, announced the support of the Campania towards 8 projects in Aeronautics R&I linked to Clean Sky 2 activities in the framework of the Aerospace technologies event “Technology Biz” of 14th November, organized by the Region in cooperation with Clean Sky 2. The projects were selected under the regional call for technology transfer under which 10 million was allocated to support complementary projects to Clean Sky 2 priorities and thus to contribute to the objectives of the MoU on synergies in place between Clean Sky and the Region. A business breakfast took place the same day between the Region, Clean Sky 2 and the 8 project coordinators, among which majority are SMEs, RTOs and Universities. These complementary projects will raise additional activities in the programme for a total budget of approximately 16 million euros. They will also contribute to the reinforcement of knowledge and creation of jobs in the aerospace sector of the Region, which is one of the regional priorities. Part of these activities will also stimulate further cooperation between Clean Sky regional members and partners, and some Industrial Leaders on various key demonstrators. During the Aerospace event, keynote speeches and contributions were made by the Regional Minister Valeria Fascione and others, including the President of CIRA Paolo Annunziato, the President of the Regional Aerospace Cluster Luigi Carrino, the Italian National Aerospace Cluster Cristina Leone, and the Italian Ministry of Defence Alessio Grasso. Alongside this, testimonials were given by Clean Sky 2, including dissemination on the call for proposal n° 9 launched on 6/11/18, Leonardo Aircraft as Leader of Clean Sky and the regional Core Partner Geven. The Regional Minister also announced the planned update of the regional smart specialization strategy in 2019, for which Clean Sky will be consulted under the MoU to guide the Region towards the technology priorities so as to ensure alignment with European roadmap and with the future framework programme post-2020.

title: Regional Clean Sky Info Day in Milan
text: On 24 October 2018, an Info Day was organised in cooperation with the Lombardia Region, Aerospace Cluster and EEN. During the Info Day, Ms Laura Savini and the President of the Aerospace Cluster, Mr Vallerani emphasised the strategic role of the Cluster for the regional ecosystem. In the Cluster there are currently 200 members from the aerospace sector with key competences. In addition, the cluster contributes to 16,000 jobs in the region and there is an overall turnover of €6 billion. The Info Day was also attended by the Regional Authority Mr Boccalani, who provided insight into the regional Research &Innovation Programme. In this programme, a call concerning €50-70 million worth of funding is expected to soon be launched to cover the RIS3 priorities including aeronautics. Marco Protti, Head of Advanced Research at Leonardo Aviation, Mr Artioli from Leonardo Helicopters and the Clean Sky 2 Governing Board also participated in the Info Day. Clean Sky 2, represented by Giuseppe Pagnano and Bruno Mastantuono, presented various key results and flagships of Clean Sky (under FP7), as well as the status of Clean Sky 2 under Horizon 2020 and a preliminary overview of the 9th Call for Proposals (CfP09) which will open in November 2018. This was followed by discussions on possible future themes for a Clean Sky 3 under Horizon Europe, and the role of the regional aerospace clusters and synergies between Clean Sky and Regional Programmes.

title: A Clean Sky 2 event in the Basque Country
text: On 30 October 2018, an Info Day was organised in Bilbao by HEGAN-the Basque Aerospace Cluster, in collaboration with SPRI, EEN‐Enterprise European Network‐ and the CDTI. The Info Day was attended by more than 70 stakeholders from academia, research, industry, SMEs, innovation agencies and regional administration. The event was opened by Iosu MADARIAGA, the Director of Technology and Strategy of the Basque Government, who highlighted the efforts undertaken by the Basque Aerospace Sector and the increased participation of Basque organizations (companies, technology centers and universities) in the regional, national and European framework programmes. He also mentioned the specific role of the CFAA (Advanced Aeronautical Manufacturing Center) in the achievement of collaborative projects in the sector. The dedicated and successful role of the HEGAN cluster in the aerospace sector was also presented by Ana Vilate, the Managing Director. She mentioned that the cluster includes 64 members, of which 9 are Core Partners in the Clean Sky 2 programme. Additionally, other members from the HEGAN cluster participate as partners in Clean Sky 2 and thus contribute to the overall high participation of the Basque country in the Clean Sky 2 programme. Clean Sky 2, represented by Michel Goulain, Bruno Mastantuono, Christos Vasilakos and Antonello Marino, presented the programme including its different technical, administrative and financial aspects. Opportunities for a closer cooperation between Clean Sky 2, the synergies and the European Structural Investment Funds were also highlighted. An overview of the 9th Call for Proposals (CfP09) which will open in November 2018 was presented and followed by four parallel sessions dedicated to six areas: Large Passenger Aircraft, Engines, Airframe, Systems, (including Technology Evaluation and Small Air Transport), Fast Rotorcraft and Regional Aircraft. These technical sessions were also supported by various Clean Sky 2 partners, such as AIRBUS and SAFRAN. In the margin of this event in Bilbao, talks took place between representatives of Clean Sky 2, the Basque Government, SPRI, HEGAN and CDTI, where opportunities for a closer collaboration and synergies within Clean Sky 2, as well as the possible future programme were discussed. For more information, please visit the link below:https://www.hegan.com/Corporativa/PNoticias.aspx?vTUxxveJgQG13aF3qvgj3pE5zUBzk4kbC62346789fFClkcmPk890785678d

title: European Technology Evaluation Workshop
text: On 17 October 2018, Clean Sky 2 organised a European Technology Evaluator workshop, which was opened with a welcome address given by Sebastiano Fumero and Tiit Jürimäe. Topics discussed include the role of technology evaluation in Research and Development decision-making, as well as the needs and ongoing activities of EU programmes. In addition, topics such as technology evaluation in shaping publicly funded research on national level, and for longer-term coordination and prioritisation of research were also elaborated upon. For more information and to see the agenda, click here.

title: Tests underway for power diode dies for more electric aircraft
text: Testing is currently underway for the Clean Sky 2 project DiDi-FaCT (Diode Die Fatigue Characterisation and Testing), part of the Systems technology platform. The project, coordinated by NLR, is focused on the area of more electric aircraft, and specifically power diodes: an electric component fitted to a generator that allows electric current to pass through in one direction only. These diodes must be able to function in extreme temperatures and under great stress, and to keep up with new smaller, faster generators. Within the DiDi-FaCT project, NLR has developed and built a dedicated test bench, and throughout 2018 is testing Thales’ ‘power diode die’ at multiple temperatures and load levels. The results of these tests will give an overview of long-term fatigue and wear, allowing the die package design to be optimised in terms of long-term reliability, which in turn paves the way for weight and efficiency improvements in generators and other equipment. Read more on NLR’s website.

title: Clean Sky debates with Regions on industrial transition
text: Clean Sky took part in the workshop on the role of the future cohesion policy in boosting industrial transition, which took place on 9 October 2018 at the Committee of the Regions, in the framework of the “European Week of Regions.” The event was opened by Natalia Gonzalez Herrera, DG for Industry and Energy of the Andalucía Region, who emphasised the key role of the EU Cohesion Policy in building local capacities and supporting industrial transition in key sectors of the European economy. The event was organised by a consortium led by Andalucía and 6 other Regions from Spain, France and Italy in close cooperation with the European Commission, Clean Sky 2 JU, EASME and various regional networks. Clean Sky 2 JU, represented by Bruno Mastantuono, stressed the importance of Public-Private Partnerships reaching out to key regional capabilities to support the Programme in achieving its goals. He also highlighted the importance of linking both the industrial plans and the smart specialisation strategies to H2020 and the future “Horizon Europe”, as well as its key EU policy priorities.  Clean Sky also informed the Regions of its model of fostering synergies with ESIF, which was described by the organisers as the best experience for fostering synergies between ERDF and H2020.

title: A Clean Sky 2 workshop in Czech Republic: looking towards the future
text: Representatives of the Czech aerospace sector, the Technology Centre of the Czech Academy of Sciences, the Ministry of Industry of the Czech Republic and other public authorities gathered in Prague on 10 October 2018 at the “International Clean Sky 2 Workshop” organized by the Ministry of Industry in cooperation with Clean Sky 2 JU, under the bilateral MoU cooperation in place since 2016. The event was opened by Mr. Vladimír Bärtl, Deputy Minister of Industry, who highlighted the importance of discussing the potential cooperation in the upcoming Clean Sky 3 with all stakeholders, and stated that the focus should be on preserving the successes of Clean Sky 2. He emphasised the strong and expanding aviation industry sector in Czech Republic, which achieved good results in Clean Sky 2 especially among EU-13 countries. He also highlighted the importance of supporting aviation, which is one of the national industrial priorities, and announced the funding of the 5 proposals submitted under the R&I complementary call to Clean Sky 2, launched by the Ministry in December 2017 to foster synergies between Clean Sky and ESIF. The Association of Czech Aerospace Industry “ALV”, represented by Joseph Kaspar, presented the strategy and vision for Aviation post-2020 and underlined the need for a dedicated National Programme for Aviation and well-targeted use of ESIF in the sector. Czech stakeholders among which Honeywell, Evektor, National Space Technologies, Latecoere and ZetJet presented key R&I activities and contributions to Clean Sky, as well as some preliminary input for possible R&I areas of intervention for the Clean Sky 3 post-2020. The Clean Sky 2 JU team represented by Ron Van Manen, Michel Goulain and Bruno Mastantuono provided information on the state of progress of Clean Sky 2, the preliminary vision for the post-2020 programme and the upcoming call for proposal n° 9. They also discussed the status of the MoU cooperation with the Czech Ministry of Industry, as well as possible areas of further cooperation with both National Programmes and ESIF, while also looking at the future post-2020 framework under discussion.    Presentations of the speakers are available under the following link:https://www.h2020.cz/cs/obecne-novinky/seminar-clean-sky-dnes-a-v-budoucnu-prezentace Direct link to ppts Clean Sky prezentace PDF.zip

title: Synergies with EU funding for defence and dual-use
text: Clean Sky participated in the “European Symposium on synergies between EU funding for defence and dual use research & innovation”, which took place in Seville on 3-4 October 2018. The event was organised by the European Commission DG Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs (DG GROW), DG Joint Research Centre (DG JRC - S3 Platform) and the Agency of Innovation of Andalusia (IDEA). The event involved discussions among public authorities (European Commission, national authorities and regions) and stakeholders about opportunities for fostering synergies between the European Structural and Investments Funds (ESIF), the newly established European Defence Fund that was presented to the participants by DG GROW, and other EU and national funding. Clean Sky, represented by Bruno Mastantuono, contributed to the session “perspectives for the future” by providing a showcase in building synergies with the ESIF in the framework of the 17 MoU partnerships in place with Member States and regions in the field of aviation R&I (read more on our synergies page at http://cleansky.eu/structural-funds-and-regions). Examples were also provided of technologies developed in Clean Sky which are suitable for potential multi-mission applications and which may be synergetic to further developments in other domains such as defence & dual-use. The importance of fostering synergies among R&I programmes and of reinforcing cooperation in areas/priorities of high innovative potential identified by the regions in their Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) was highlighted by the speakers as a key factor for strengthening the European industrial base and growth in strategic sectors, whilst enhancing regional competitiveness.  The presentations of all the sessions will be made available on the website of the conferencehttps://dualuseandalucia2018.b2match.io/my/agenda

title: RACER passes preliminary design review milestone
text: Clean Sky 2’s RACER demonstrator for Fast Rotorcraft has reached a major milestone in its development with a successful preliminary design review, following the validation of the demonstrator’s aerodynamic configuration in 2017. RACER aims to provide the best trade-off between speed, cost-efficiency, sustainability and mission performance. Long-lead items are already being manufactured for RACER. Airbus Helicopters has already launched production of the lateral drive shaft, one of the most innovative components for the demonstrator. Other partners working on the project include GE Avio (procurement and manufacturing for the lateral gear boxes housing); GE Aviation Systems (the wing’s titanium cradle part); INCAS/Romaero (the composite side panel) and Aernnova (the tail parts primary structure). “I want to thank all of our European partners for the excellence of their work and for their commitment in this fantastic project”, said Tomasz Krysinski, Head of Research & Innovation at Airbus Helicopters. “The PDR marks a major achievement for the Racer program as it allows to freeze interfaces and 3D definitions of the main subsystems, prior to detailed design and manufacture of key components” Final assembly of the RACER demonstrator is planned to start in Q4 2019. Airbus Helicopters and its partners are currently refining the content of the future RACER flight demonstration in Clean Sky 2 which will begin in 2020 and include about 200 flight hours. The first part will focus on the progressive opening of the flight envelope and on assessing key performance objectives as well as speed, handling qualities, stability and aerodynamics. The second phase will aim to demonstrate RACER’s suitability to carry out missions where increased speed and efficiency would bring significant added value, such as emergency medical services and search & rescue, and will also focus on maturing low-noise flight procedures which are a key aim of RACER. Read the press release from Airbus Helicopters here.

title: 3D printing makes Rolls-Royce’s Advance3 lighter and more efficient
text: Rolls-Royce’s Advance3 demonstrator engine has now completed over 100 test hours and is showing excellent results from parts made through 3D printing, or additive layer manufacturing (ALM), and from ceramic matrix composites (CMC). The advantages of ALM include quicker design and manufacturing: complex engine parts with multiple pieces can be manufactured in fewer parts or even as a single complete part, improving lead times and allowing components to be redesigned quickly and easily during the development phase. ALM also increases production efficiency and reduces component weight. Meanwhile CMCs are lighter than metal alternatives and can withstand higher temperatures for longer, contributing to improved efficiency. To date, engineers have downloaded millions of data points from the tests, which began last November and saw the engine achieve full power in July 2018. The Advance3 demonstrator is testing a new engine core that will deliver optimum fuel efficiency and low emissions. It is a key element in Rolls-Royce’s future technology strategy to develop the Advance core for the UltraFan® engine design that will be available from 2025 and will offer a 25% improvement in fuel efficiency compared with a first generation Trent engine. The Advance3 demonstrator programme is co-funded through the Aerospace Technology Institute (ATI) in association with Innovate UK and Clean Sky 2. See Rolls-Royce press release here https://www.rolls-royce.com/media/press-releases/2018/11-10-2018-3-d-printed-parts-and-new-materials-help-rolls-royce-to-engine-test-success.aspx

title: Clean Sky discusses best practices on synergies between European programmes
text: Clean Sky participated in the European conference ‘EU Funding for Defence and Security Projects: Opportunities in the New EDF and Synergies with ESIF’ that took place in Berlin on 27-28 September 2018. The conference was organised by the German European Academy for Taxes, Economics & Law and was attended by representatives from EU institutions, EIB, ministries, national authorities and other related stakeholders. Christos Vasilakos (Clean Sky, Policy Officer for Synergies) chaired the session ‘Building Synergies Between ERDF & H2020 in Order to Maximise the Impact of EU Research & Innovation (R&I) Investments’ and presented the opportunities for synergies within the new Multi-Annual Programme 2021-2027, as well as the best practices from the synergies with ESIF that are currently implemented by Clean Sky. He highlighted Clean Sky’s on-going action plan for cooperation with Member States and Regions that has resulted in 17 MoU at a national or regional level to date, and a number of pilot projects funded by ESIF. He also stressed the perspectives for synergies between the European Defence Fund and other EU programmes, such as Horizon Europe, ERDF and CEF. The other speakers presented the possibilities for research projects under the new European Defence Fund, further funding opportunities that could be used for defence activities within HORIZON 2020, COSME & ERASMUS+, and their experiences of the management of defence related projects. The importance of funding opportunities for dual-use R&I activities was highlighted as well as the possibilities for industrial development through the support of defence, security and dual-use research activities.

title: PIPS project for innovative ice protection system passes first tests
text: The Clean Sky 2 project PIPS (Passive Ice Protection System) has reached its first important milestone with a test of the complete system with actual hardware. The project, which is run by the Belgian company EHP as partner and Airbus DS as Topic Manager, was tested at EHP premises near Brussels. The project’s objective is to obtain a competitive ice protection system in terms of weight while minimising energy requirements by application of the highly efficient and passive biphasic capillary pumping heat transport technology. The biphasic capillary pumping technology, developed initially for space application, is characterised by 1) high capacity of heat transport between a heat source and a heat sink, and 2) no need of external power nor moving parts to move the fluid transporting the heat. It basically consists of five parts: 1) evaporator, 2) fluid reservoir, 3) condenser, 4) fluid transport lines and 5) fluid to transport the heat between evaporator and condenser. It operates passively by means of the capillary forces generated in a metallic porous structure (called “wick”) embedded in the evaporator when liquid is transformed to vapor. Two major variants exist, the so-called Loop Heat Pipe (LHP) and the Capillary Pumped Loop (CPL), with the difference between the two being the fact that the reservoir is attached to the evaporator (LHP) and not (CPL). The fluid reservoir defines the working point of the fluid circulating in the loop. The major challenges of the project are the “wick” capillary pumping capacity in order to cope the positive acceleration forces which are present in aircraft and not in space application, the maximum temperature of the heat source (in this case 250 deg C) while typically it does not exceed 100 deg C, and the integration of the condensing lines inside a geometrically complex structure like a chin type engine air intake. The recent test is crucial in terms of validating the analytical performances model of the system prior to construction of the system to be fitted in engine air intake and nacelle mockup, which will be tested in Icing Wind Tunnel at Rail Tech Arsenal in Austria in the Clean Sky 2 project I3PS (Integrated Innovative Ice Protection System) by the beginning of 2020.

title: First lessons learned for Clean Sky 2 project on effects of using VR headsets on-board
text: Clean Sky 2’s Immersive Cabin Project (IMCA), studying the effects of wearing virtual reality and augmented reality headsets by airplane passengers, was put to the test for the first time last week. The project, led by NLR, is looking at how using a VR headset affects passengers in response to safety, on-board service, experience and comfort. Last week’s test, which took place in a KLM cabin simulator at Schiphol-East, saw a group of forty KLM volunteers and a crew being exposed to various flight scenarios, such as a calm flight and turbulence, while either viewing a presentation on a VR headset or on their smartphone. During the tests, the cabin crew found they had to make more effort to communicate with those passengers wearing the headsets; it was particularly noted during the turbulence simulation that many headset wearers were unaware of any emergency at all. The passengers’ responses, recorded on video and through a questionnaire, are still to be analysed, but the tests seem to confirm the researchers’ hypothesis that wearing a VR headset affects communications between crew and passengers, leading to negative consequences for on-board services and even safety. More conclusive results are expected this autumn. Read the experience of one of the KLM test subjects: https://blog.klm.com/the-future-of-virtual-reality-on-board/ Read more about the project on NLR’s website: https://www.nlr.org/news/klm-and-nlr-test-effects-of-using-virtual-reality-headsets-in-cabin-simulator/

title: Clean Sky at Farnborough Airshow: Day 5: Futures Day & Public Days
text: Today is Futures Day at Farnborough! Don’t miss the opportunity to simulate your flight at our stand! We have a 50” tactile screen with the new Clean Sky application where you can choose your flight destination from London and experience our flight simulation. You can directly compare the differences between a ‘standard flight’ and a Clean Sky flight: aircraft differences and how these translate in CO2 and noise reduction. You will experience the flight with great visuals and be able to see the results for your own selected flight. You can also browse through our technologies if you want to learn more about what we have achieved so far! Thank you to all the visitors who passed or are planning to pass by our stand this week to see examples of Clean Sky innovative technologies and achievements! title: Clean Sky Green Rotorcraft project wins Grover E. Bell Award
text: The Clean Sky 1 Optimised Passive Rotor Blade project, led by Airbus Helicopters Deutschland as part of the Green Rotorcraft platform (GRC), has won the Grover E. Bell Award for outstanding contributions in research and experimentation in vertical flight. The initial aim of the project was to test a scaled passive rotor in a wind tunnel and reach TRL4. Clean Sky JU supported the Airbus Helicopters Deutschland proposal to go beyond this based on their rapid improvement of simulation capabilities and tools, and finally a full-scale rotor was developed, built and tested in flight, reaching TRL6. The achieved results contributed strongly to the Clean Sky objectives of minimising the environmental footprint of flying vehicles, in this case specifically the reduction of noise and noise annoyance of a rotorcraft. The award was received by Stefanie Link, the project leader from the Airbus Helicopters Deutschland GRC team, at a ceremony on 16 May in Phoenix, Arizona (US), during the annual AHS Forum.

title: Campania Region support to aerospace R&I
text: The Campania Region published on 21 May 2018 a public notice on the support of regional stakeholders within the areas of the ‘regional smart specialisations strategy’ (RIS3) priorities, which includes ‘Aerospace’ amongst other priorities. Under the notice, projects of technology transfer and for industrial take-up of innovative companies may be supported. Within this category of projects, a specific budget of €10 million was allocated to support, with priority, proposals that will fall within the technology priorities identified by the Region in the field of aerospace and which have been identified as being coherent and contributing to the objectives of Clean Sky 2. This instrument will stimulate synergies and complementarities between the Clean Sky 2 programme and the ERDF Regional Operational Programme 2014-2020 with direct support to the stakeholders, and thus will contribute to implementing the goals of the Memorandum of Understanding on synergies in place between the Campania Region and Clean Sky 2 JU. Campania is amongst the European Regions with the highest success rate of stakeholders in the open calls launched by the Clean Sky 2 JU and its variety of stakeholders (industry, SMEs, research organisations and universities) are represented at all programme levels (Leaders, Core Partners and Partners).   Read more about Clean Sky’s work with Member States and Regions in our updated brochure. The public notice and the accompanying documents including the list of the technology priorities in Aerospace are available at the following link: http://porfesr.regione.campania.it/it/news/primo-piano/innovazione-e-trasferimento-tecnologico-sostegno-alle-imprese-campane-nella-realizzazione-di-studi-di-fattibilita-fase-1-e-progetti-fase-2-coerenti-con-la-ris3

title: A step forward for the UltraFan: Airbus and Rolls-Royce sign collaboration agreement
text: A collaboration agreement has been signed by Airbus and Rolls-Royce for the integration of Rolls-Royce’s UltraFan demonstrator for flight testing within Clean Sky 2. Rolls-Royce has agreed to provide both nacelle and engine/aircraft integration architecture and technology enablers for UltraFan ground and flight tests, while Airbus integration solutions will play an important part in achieving the overall fuel efficiency improvement of higher bypass ratio engines such as UltraFan through innovative architecture and associated technologies. UltraFan features a new engine core architecture and lean-burn combustion system which will contribute to improved fuel burn efficiency and lower emissions, along with a carbon titanium fan blade system and composite casing which reduce weight. The engine also introduces a geared design to deliver efficient power at high-bypass ratios. UltraFan aims to offer a 25 % fuel efficiency improvement over the first generation of the Rolls-Royce Trent engine.

title: Clean Sky at Transport Research Arena (TRA)
text: Clean Sky was present at the Transport Research Arena (TRA) in Vienna from 16 to 19 April at the stand of the European Commission, who co-organised the conference. Clean Sky showcased a model of the BLADE test aircraft for laminar flow, which aims to reduce wing friction drag by 50 % and aircraft CO₂ emissions by up to 5 %, and also gave presentations during the event: Interim Executive Director Tiit Jürimäe joined a panel discussion on ‘Enabling and Implementing Research and Innovation Strategies’ on Thursday 19 April and Giuseppe Pagnano gave an insight into Clean Sky’s progress to date on Wednesday 18 April. TRA 2018 brought together policy makers and stakeholders framing research and transport policy to discuss new ideas, research results and technological solutions. Key focus areas over the four days included digitalisation, decarbonisation, competitiveness and the transport of the future. See the overview of the event including pictures and videos on the TRA website now, and watch the video message from Commissioner Carlos Moedas here.

title: Clean Sky at ILA Berlin: Day D-1: One day until take off!
text: Clean Sky's week at ILA Berlin takes off tomorrow and for the first time ever Clean Sky and the European Commission jointly open a stand at ILA Berlin 2018, welcoming visitors who include key policymakers, industry experts and researchers. From 25 to 29 April, the exhibition stand presents an opportunity not only to learn about Clean Sky's work and goals to reduce CO2, gas emissions and noise levels produced by aircraft but also to appreciate several pieces of innovative hardware developed through the Clean Sky programme. Such hardware includes: BLADE model RACER model AIRMES VR system Regional Passenger Cabin Ground Demonstrator Innovative Regional Turboprop Aircraft Configuration model (Loop#2) Examples of Eco-Design: CFRP-recycling application, advanced engine manufacturing and low-weight reusable bio-materials HoloLens AR system showing the Open rotor Rolls-Royce UltraFan App MTU FutureLab App Interactive display showing Clean Sky's contribution to greener aviation The Clean Sky team at stand no 304 look forward to meeting you.

title: Clean Sky joins the 2018 Earth Hour initiative
text: On Saturday, 24th of March, between 20.30 and 21.30 Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking will join 21 EU Institutions and all other JUs in the campaign Earth Hour 2018 - EU Institutions and bodies go "beyond the hour" sponsored also by the EMAS (European Commission’s environmental management system). As a result the White Atrium building will symbolically switch off the lights in the offices and on the facades (besides any security and legal compliance restrictions) to save power and help save the planet. Earth Hour 2018 is a WWF initiative, this year celebrating its 11th anniversary (see WWF video). We wish to take this opportunity to invite you to respect a simple principle: "a few everyday actions are enough to actively contribute to sustainable development: just turn off the light or the PC or other electronic device you're using when you leave the room." More guidance on EMAS policies on http://ec.europa.eu/environment/emas/index_en.htm   Clean Sky 2 JU Management

title: Clean Sky 2 awards first Synergy Certificate with ESIF
text: The first ‘Synergy Certificate’ with the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF) was awarded by the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking to the project “Composite Automation Development Centre [CADC]” in recognition of implementing synergies with ESIF in the context of the Memorandum of Understanding signed between the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking and the Netherlands’ Province of Zuid-Holland. The Certificate was officially presented to the project coordinator in the presence of the Provincie and the Regional Managing Authority on Friday 6 April.   The CADC initiative will support innovative research and technology linked to advanced and automation (robotics) enabled composite manufacturing, in synergy and complementarity with the Clean Sky 2 Programme; and it has been successfully evaluated and selected for funding by Managing Authority ERDF Opportunities for West. The research and innovation, and demonstration activities, will enable strong synergies to be created with the work from both TU Delft and GKN/Fokker, Clean Sky 2 Core Partners, in Large Passenger Aircraft (LPA) and Airframe (AIR). Alongside coordinator TU Delft, the other participants are GKN/Fokker, TNO, KVE, GTM, Airbus Defense and Space (Netherlands), Suzlon, and Airborne.   The CADC programme supports the set up and launch of SAM/XL (Smart Advanced Manufacturing XL): a collaborative research centre with shared facilities, where technology is being developed, demonstrated, and de-risked for the automated manufacture of large-scale lightweight composite parts for aircraft, wind turbine blades, and spacecraft. This will help prepare the aerospace manufacturing supply chain for the ‘Industry 4.0’ agenda and digitisation revolution in manufacturing, and support the ramp-up and automation of aircraft structures, laying a solid technological and industrial foundation for future aircraft programmes.

title: 8th Call for Proposals now open!
text: Clean Sky 2’s 8th Call for Proposals was published on 12 April. This call includes 68 topics and a total indicative funding of €75 million. The deadline is 12 July 2018. Visit our Calls for Proposals page for more information.

title: Workshop on developing synergies between Joint Undertakings and ESIF
text: A workshop dedicated to ‘Developing synergies between Joint Undertakings and ESIF for optimising RIS3 implementation’ was co-organised on 7 March by DG JRC, DG REGIO, the Committee of the Regions, and the Joint Undertakings Clean Sky, Fuel Cells and Hydrogen (FCH), and Bio Based Industries (BBI). The overall objective was to promote collaboration in support of RIS3 implementation, highlighting activities under the MoU and exchanging best practices among Member States/Regions. Key messages from speakers Markku Markkula (Vice President, the Committee of the Regions), Lambert van Nistelrooij (MEP) and Magda de Carli (Head of Unit, DG RTD, European Commission) focused on the importance of involving the Regions and Member States in a bottom-up approach to innovation in order to achieve sustainable growth and European leadership in a variety of sectors. The Joint Undertakings were positively highlighted as key actors in fostering synergies and European cross-border partnerships. A second panel discussion included perspectives from DG JRC and the three Joint Undertakings, as well as the collaboration opportunities for the Regions. Clean Sky presented the concrete examples already being implemented as a result of its 16 Memoranda of Understanding signed with various Regions and Member States, such as the national and regional calls launched by Czech Republic and Andalucía, which were elaborated by local representatives in the afternoon session. During the afternoon parallel sessions the regional representatives exchanged their experiences and best practices on how they are establishing collaborations with JUs, not only targeting synergies between ESIF and JU calls but also in terms of capacity building at regional level to participate in H2020, raising awareness or building research and education capacities. The workshop was completed with some key conclusions that were raised from the discussions and presented by the representatives of the JUs.   Presentations from the workshop are available here. Learn more about Clean Sky’s work with Member States and Regions here.

title: Clean Sky 2’s RACER helicopter lands in Spain
text: Clean Sky 2’s fast helicopter RACER was introduced to the general public at an event organised by Airbus Helicopters Espana SA on Tuesday 30 January in Albacete, in the Castilla-La Mancha region of Spain. The event was attended by Spanish partners and Core Partners in Clean Sky who are contributing to the programme through projects launched within the Airframe platform. The event also featured a press conference in which Mr Tomasz Krysinski, R&D Director of Airbus Helicopters, presented the RACER programme in detail, highlighting the current development under Clean Sky 2 and a bold vision for the future towards intercity mobility. The synergies between Clean Sky 2 and the Castilla-La Mancha region were put in focus at the event. The region signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Clean Sky in April 2016, and has already had two regional calls: the pilot project MULTIDRILL was selected from the first, and the second was launched in January 2018. Questions at the event were answered by Andrzej B. Podsadowski (Fast Rotorcraft Project Officer, Clean Sky), and by a representative of the Castilla-La Mancha government, Mr Francisco Javier Rosell Perez (Director General for the Development of Economic Strategy and European Affairs / Empresas, Competitividad e Internacionalization). This was followed by an internal review of the programme for the Spanish partners involved in RACER.

title: BLADE wins 2018 Laureate Award for Technology
text: Thanks to its technology, the BLADE (Breakthrough Laminar Aircraft Demonstrator in Europe) has won its place amongst Aviation Week’s 61st Annual Laureate Award Winners for Business, Defense, Space, and Commercial Aviation. Under the Clean Sky research programme, Airbus’ heavily modified A340 laminar-flow testbed, BLADE, entered flight testing in 2017. The goal is to prove that natural laminar flow can be made practical and usable, reducing wing friction drag by 50% and aircraft CO₂ emissions by up to 5%. Aviation Week’s 61st Annual Laureate Awards Ceremony recognised the winners’ achievements on Thursday, 1 March 2018 at the National Building Museum, Washington, DC. Learn about the full BLADE story here.

title: Clean Sky Academy Award for Best PhD Thesis in Applied Sciences and Engineering for Aeronautics
text: The Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking is pleased to announce the third edition of this Award to distinguish young scientists who have recently completed a PhD thesis in the field of aeronautics. The Award acknowledges outstanding achievements of three young persons at the start of their scientific careers, and it will be presented at a dedicated ceremony at the ILA Berlin Air Show on 25 April 2018.   The deadline for application is 1 March 2018, 17:00 (Brussels time).   More information: Rules and guidelines for applications Application template

title: A regional call launched by Castilla-La Mancha Region
text: On 5 December 2017, the Castilla-La Mancha region in Spain published a regional call in the Official Gazette of Castilla-La Mancha. The call is a general competitive call where companies, also from the aeronautical sector (which is a RIS3 priority of Castilla-La Mancha Region), can submit proposals in the field. This call also provides some favorable conditions to the proposals which have a positive evaluation by the Clean Sky 2 programme, such as proposals in the reserve lists of the Clean Sky calls (which may still be considered valid for both the stakeholder and Clean Sky 2 as complementary activities) or proposals of complementary activities. Regional stakeholders participating in Clean Sky 2, or stakeholders who have an interest in Clean Sky 2 topics and objectives, are encouraged to consider their participation in this call which aims to implement the Memorandum of Understanding between Clean Sky 2 and Castilla-La Mancha Region and foster synergies. Read more about the call published:  https://www.jccm.es/tramitesygestiones/programa-innova-adelante

title: Clean Sky visit to NLR and DNW
text: In February the Clean Sky team was welcomed by participants NLR (Netherlands Aerospace Centre) and DNW (German-Dutch Wind Tunnels), to discover their work towards Clean Sky’s environmental objectives. Both organisations are based in Marknesse, Netherlands. The NLR team gave a tour of their composite ‘Pilot Plant’ where large high-stress composite structures are manufactured via robotics. This facility is involved in the Clean Sky 2 composite Landing Gear project and produces a key part of the Joint Strike Fighter landing gear in collaboration with GKN/Fokker. This was followed by a tour by DNW of their Large Scale Facility, the largest (low speed) Wind Tunnel in Europe, which has been used inter alia for wind tunnel and noise tests for Clean Sky’s Open Rotor. Thank you to NLR and DNW for this interesting visit!

title: Clean Sky 2 welcomes E-Fan X Hybrid-Electric flight partnership
text: The Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking welcomes the announcement made on 28 November 2017 by Airbus, Rolls-Royce and Siemens to form a partnership launching the E-Fan X hybrid-electric flight demonstrator. The partnership aims at developing a near-term flight demonstrator which will be a significant step forward in hybrid-electric propulsion for commercial aircraft. This partnership will develop and demonstrate technologies which seamlessly complement the Clean Sky 2 Programme’s technology development related to hybrid-electric propulsion under the Large Passenger Aircraft platform, and use important building blocks and results from Clean Sky 2 in its ambitious next step towards flight demonstration. They are fully consistent with the Flightpath 2050 Strategy and will play a key role in meeting the ACARE SRIA goals for energy efficiency and reduced emissions. The European aeronautics sector has championed the development of clean, quiet and energy-efficient technologies over several decades of research, leveraging the sector’s world-leading capabilities and investment with the European Union Framework Programme  and Member States’ funding for research, and engaging with the academic and scientific research base across the EU. This has already led to aircraft becoming 75% more efficient and environmentally friendly than the first generation of jet aircraft. But the search for further gains is relentless, as only in this way will the air transport sector be able to continue to grow and serve the Europe’s citizens in terms of travel and mobility options. Hybrid-electric propulsion is one of the “new frontiers” in the search for new technological approaches.   Read more here: http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/topics-in-focus/electrification.html https://www.rolls-royce.com/media/press-releases/yr-2017/28-11-2017-airbus-rr-and-siemens-team-up-for-electric-future.aspx http://www.cleansky.eu/large-passenger-aircraft

title: ‘Readynov 2018’ call launched by Occitanie Region
text: The Occitanie Region of France has recently launched the “Readynov 2018” call dedicated to aeronautics and related industries. The call covers a number of topics related to aeronautic technologies, and aims to support proposals linked to Clean Sky 2 related topics (ref. to the CSJU Work Plan) or which contribute to Clean Sky 2 objectives. Regional stakeholders participating in Clean Sky 2, or stakeholders who have an interest in Clean Sky 2 topics and objectives, are encouraged to consider this call which contributes to the implementation of the renewed MoU between Clean Sky 2 and Occitanie Region, and promotes the Synergies with the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF). The closure date is 11 April 2018. Read more about the call published: https://www.laregion.fr/Appel-a-projets-READYNOV-Aerospatial-et-Industries-de-pointe      The Occitanie Region also launched in December 2017 the “Programme d’Investissements d’Avenir (PIA3) Action: «Occitanie Projets d’Innovation PIA3» Appel à projets”. This call funds feasibility studies or experimental developments. Depending on the proposals, complementary projects linked to Clean Sky 2 related topics may be identified and considered for funding under the MoU. This call will be open for one year and until funds are available.  Read more about the call published: http://pia3innovation-occitanie.laregion.fr/

title: Public consultation launched on EU funding for research and innovation
text: The European Commission today launched a public consultation on the EU budget for funding research and innovation after 2020. The consultation asks for feedback on investments in the successor to the Horizon 2020 programme, the single market, small- and medium-sized businesses and other financial assistance programmes to foster innovation. The comments received will be evaluated as the Commission prepares its proposal for the next Multi-Annual Financial Framework, to run from 2021-2027. The consultation is open until 8 March. Give your opinion here.

title: Successful first run for Rolls-Royce’s Advance3 demonstrator engine
text: Celebrations were in order last Friday 1 December as Rolls-Royce’s Advance3 demonstrator engine successfully ran for the first time. The Advance3 programme is co-funded through the Aerospace Technology Institute (ATI) in association with Innovate UK and Clean Sky 2. Comprising a new core design, married to a Trent XWB fan system and a Trent 1000 low pressure turbine, the Advance3 engine performed as expected during the initial test, which lasted for just under an hour. It incorporates a range of cutting-edge technologies including ceramic matrix composite materials, a new specialist turbine manufacturing method (CastBond™), the lean burn combustion system and some 3D printed components. Rolls-Royce’s Andy Geer leads the 500-strong global team responsible for the Advance3. He said: “This is no ordinary programme. The new core is a major, fundamental architectural change and for the engine to work right first time is a fantastic achievement. The team has worked so hard to make this design come to life and my heartfelt thanks go to everyone who has contributed. But this isn’t just about one engine or one test. Since the new core is at the heart of our future engine concepts, our ongoing work has far reaching implications for the business.” The new core will be deployed by UltraFan®, which aims to offer a 25% fuel efficiency improvement compared with the first generation of Trent engine, and which will be available for service from 2025. The engine will continue testing in Derby, UK, with future tests gathering data on the performance of the engine across more than 2,800 parameters. Read the press release here

title: Complementary call to Clean Sky 2 launched by Czech Republic
text: A ‘complementary call to Clean Sky 2 under the National Programme Aplikace’ was launched by the Ministry of Industry and Trade of Czech Republic on 30 November, as a result of the implementation of the MoU cooperation signed with Clean Sky 2 JU in 2016. The call aims at supporting RDI projects complementary to Clean Sky 2 and its technical scope as defined in the CS2JU Work Plan and has a total budget of 400 Million CZK (around €15.5 million) from the European Structural and Investment Funds. Eligible applicants are consortia-only, composed of Large Enterprises, SMEs and possibly Research Organisations. The deadline for submission of applications is 30 April 2018. The text of the call and all supporting documents can be found here Watch the video presentation of the call by Marcela Příhodová, Ministry of Industry and Trade:

title: €30 billion still available for research within Horizon 2020 Programme
text: Horizon 2020 is the European Union's €77 billion flagship funding programme for research and innovation running from 2014 to 2020. As well as providing funds for the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking Public-Private Partnership and the other Joint Undertakings, Horizon 2020 also funds numerous areas of research. The new €30 billion Work Programme 2018-2020 includes topics of interest to those in aviation.   The €945 million Smart, Green and Integrated Transport Work Programme 2018-2020 reflects the European Commission's priorities in its policy goals.   Of the Calls for Proposals, the Mobility for Growth (MG) call is most relevant to aviation stakeholders. However the other two calls – on automated road transport and on green vehicles – may have topics that are also of interest.   Amongst the 2018 MG call topics – that opened on 31 October 2017 – the following relate directly to aviation: LC-MG-1-1-2018: International Cooperation (InCo) flagship on Air Quality – Reduction of transport impact on air quality (EUR 30 m); MG-2-1-2018: Human Factors in Transport Safety (EUR 18 m); MG-2-3-2018: Airworthiness of mass-market drones (EUR 3 m); MG-2-5-2018: InCo flagship on Aviation – Innovative technologies for improving aviation safety and certification in icing conditions (EUR 16 m); MG-3-1-2018: Multidisciplinary and collaborative aircraft design tools and processes (EUR 12 m).   The 2019 MG call topics that are directly related to aviation are the following: Opening 5 September: LC-MG-1-5-2019: Advancements in aerodynamics & innovative propulsion systems for quieter & greener aircrafts (EUR 15 m); MG-2-8-2019: Innovative applications of drones for ensuring safety in transport (EUR 15 m). Opening 4 December: LC-MG-1-6-2019: InCo flagship on Aviation – aviation operations' impact on climate change (EUR 10 m); LC-MG-1-7-2019: InCo flagship on Aviation – Future propulsion & integration: towards a hybrid/ electric aircraft (EUR 15 m).   Links: Transport Work Programme 2018-2020 Horizon 2020 homepage Horizon 2020 calls homepage

title: Call for expressions of interest for the selection of members of the Clean Sky Scientific Committee
text: Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking has opened a call for expressions of interest for the selection of members of the Scientific Committee (SciCom). The SciCom is composed of high-level scientists and engineers. Its purpose is to focus on the scientific and technical analysis of the outcome of Clean Sky 1 and the implementation of Clean Sky 2 Programmes from different perspectives: environmental impact, technology and scientific forecast, societal impact and economics. Applications must be sent by email to: monica.sala@cleansky.eu, by 30 November 2017. The title and exact reference of the call for expression of interest should be indicated in the subject of the e-mail. Find all details here
