title: Clean Sky at the 3rd EU Aeronautics Conference: How to Drive Innovation and Competitiveness?
text: Clean Sky was present at the 3rd EU Aeronautics Conference: How to Drive Innovation and Competitiveness? which took place in the European Parliament in Brussels on 18 October 2017. The annual conference, initiated by the European Parliament’s Sky and Space Intergroup (SSI) with the support of ASD (the AeroSpace and Defence Industries Association of Europe), provided an important opportunity for industrial stakeholders, labour unions, research centres and organisations from different sectors to exchange views and knowledge with high-level decision-makers from the Parliament, the Commission and the Council. Some of the key speakers included President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani, Vice-President of the European Commission Maroš Šefčovič, Commissioner for Transport Violeta Bulc and Commissioner for Digital Economy and Society Mariya Gabriel, as well as CEO of Airbus Tom Enders, CEO of Rolls Royce Warren East and Clean Sky Interim Executive Director Tiit Jürimäe, who elaborated on ideas of how to achieve sustainable aviation with lower CO₂ and noise levels. In its third edition, the conference dealt in plenary and working group sessions with challenges and opportunities such as the next European Framework Programme for Research & Innovation (R&I), the international competitiveness and level playing field, efforts aimed at a sustainable industry and greener aviation and the role of digitization in building Europe’s intelligent air transport system. The aim of the conference was to produce tangible working results aiming to inspire future political initiatives at EU level. To learn more about the event, click here To read the report, click here

title: Skyline 23: Broadening Clean Sky Horizons
text: Skyline 23 has arrived! This issue showcases two of Clean Sky’s flagship projects – the BLADE laminar flow wing demonstrator and the Open Rotor engine – which have successfully started their test campaigns. Learn more about the EU Horizon 2020 innovative technologies and European collaborative spirit which have made these projects possible! This issue also highlights the wider research community around Clean Sky, with views from the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), SESAR JU, Shift2Rail JU and FCH JU. Clean Sky’s ongoing efforts with Member States and Regions feature too, with concrete actions now being seen. Cheryl Atkinson, an independent expert on the review panel for Clean Sky’s evaluations, also shares her insights into the evaluation process and findings in this issue of Skyline. Finally, we hope you enjoy a look back at Clean Sky’s participation in Le Bourget in June as well as an overview of our next events. Read Skyline 23 here.

title: EU financing of research and innovation in aeronautics post-2020
text: A debate on ‘Green Aviation and EU financing of Research & Innovation in Aviation post-2020’ took place on 27 September in Brussels. The debate was organised by the Permanent Representation of the Czech Republic to the EU and CEBRE, the Czech Business Representation to the EU in cooperation with Clean Sky 2 JU. Keynote speakers included Tomáš Novotný, Deputy Minister of Industry and Trade of the Czech Republic; Clara de la Torre, Director of Transport in DG RTD, European Commission; and Christian Ehler, Member of the European Parliament. A second panel of speakers was made up of Mateusz Gaczyński, Ministry of Science and Higher Education of Poland; Nathalie Errard, Senior Vice President of Airbus; Katja Reppel, Deputy Head of Unit for Regional  Policy, European Commission; and Joeri De Ruytter, R&T Business Development and Partnerships, Honeywell. Main interventions focused on the importance of visible impact of EU aeronautics programmes to show their value to citizens, and that by financing research and innovation in the aviation sector, a stronger industry and ecosystem is created with a greater socio-economic impact. Concrete Clean Sky achievements were highlighted, including the BLADE flight demonstration on 26 September in Tarbes, France. As part of the keynote session, Clara de la Torre mentioned the mobility package recently published by the Commission and its links with clean and competitive technologies. She also mentioned the ongoing review work in the Commission based on the “evolutionary” recommendations from the High Level Experts Group chaired by Pascal Lamy, such as the mission-oriented R&I with a clear and trans-disciplinary impact. She stressed the importance of the EU and Member States working together and pooling efforts in aviation, as well as the need to show the impact of R&I funded research on citizens’ daily lives and the importance of a sound regulatory framework. Finally, she highlighted being proud of Clean Sky’s results so far. Christian Ehler elaborated on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and political budget negotiations for post-2020, warning about the implications of Brexit for the JTIs and the need to have a clear framework as soon as possible. He also touched on Europe’s level of ambition for the next Framework Programme, as well as the issue of the innovation gap in Europe which must be addressed and in which JTIs can play a role. He stressed the importance of a continuation of Clean Sky under the next Framework Programme, noting that Clean Sky is working effectively on synergies with ESIF with Member States and Regions, such as the Czech Republic, to contribute to more coordinated investments in R&I in aviation. Tomáš Novotný emphasised the importance of aviation as a growing sector in Czech Republic by showing figures on turnover and job creation. He highlighted the positive cooperation with Clean Sky under the MoU signed in 2016 and announced a national thematic call in aviation to support complementarities with the Clean Sky 2 programme. He also stressed the importance of re-orientating the stakeholders to European programmes in light of a possible reduction of funds under the future cohesion policy. Looking to the future, a number of challenges facing the European aeronautics industry were touched upon by the panel discussion including the level of ambition that the future Framework Programme and possible Clean Sky 3 should have; important technology topics such as the electrification of aircraft and the increasing digitalisation of the sector; and the emergence of new competitors such as Brazil and China. It was emphasised that this is an integrated sector with spill-over from aerospace and defence, and an integrated industry effort in a global competition. It was also mentioned that the pace of innovation in Europe must be stepped up in order not to fall behind and that EU financing through Public-Private Partnerships is crucial for this, with Clean Sky being a fundamental pillar: not just a bridge for innovation, but an accelerator.  Although the future of EU financing for the aviation sector is still unknown, considering the dimension of Brexit and future cohesion policy, several speakers noted that financing should continue to focus on mobilising activities around missions and working across disciplines and borders to truly have a positive impact on citizens’ lives.   Read the press release from the debate here View speakers’ presentations here

title: Eric Dautriat wins CEAS Gold Medal Award
text: Eric Dautriat, former Executive Director of Clean Sky, has received the CEAS Gold Medal Award for outstanding contributions to the aeronautical sciences. The prize was awarded during the 6th CEAS Air & Space Conference, in Bucharest from 16-20 October. Eric Dautriat was the Executive Director of Clean Sky until September 2016 when his seven year mandate ended. Congratulations to Eric Dautriat!

title: Clean Sky BLADE laminar flow demonstrator makes first flight!
text: Clean Sky’s Breakthrough Laminar Aircraft Demonstrator in Europe (BLADE), led by Airbus, was flight-tested today between Tarbes and Toulouse. The Demonstrator aims at bringing about a 50% reduction of wing friction and up to five percent lower CO2 emission. It is the first test aircraft in the world combining a transonic laminar wing profile with a standard aircraft internal primary structure.   BLADE is part of Clean Sky’s Smart Fixed Wing Aircraft programme within the EU Horizon 2020 research & innovation vision.   Read the press release here Click here to check the video Follow the BLADE story right from the beginning with our infographic!

title: Successful ground test for the Open Rotor!
text: The Contra-Rotating Open Rotor demonstrator, part of Clean Sky’s Sustainable and Green Engines programme, reached an important milestone on 3 October in Istres, France, with the first ground test by Safran in their new test cell. This landmark testing brought together Philippe Petitcolin, Chief Executive Officer of Safran, and Ross McInnes, Chairman of the board, as well as European Commission and Clean Sky representatives Clara de la Torre and Tiit Jürimäe. Designed to power upcoming generations of single-aisle commercial jets, the Open Rotor aims to reduce fuel consumption and CO2 emission by about 30%. Its revolutionary architecture marks a significant break with current engine technology. The Open Rotor project, led by Safran, involves some 50 participants across Europe and has a budget of €127 million, reflecting the excellence of Europe’s aeronautical R&D. Read the press release on Safran’s website. Check out this video on the Open Rotor on Clean Sky’s YouTube playlist.

title: Clean Sky 2 Horizon 2020 Interim Evaluation: a very positive picture of the programme so far
text: On 9 October the European Commission published the interim evaluation (2014-2016) of the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking operating under Horizon 2020. The report highlights the main areas of achievements of Clean Sky 2 such as a high-quality research capability, a good balance of industrial, research and aeronautics activities and high engagement of European SMEs. In particular, the independent experts in charge of the report underline the “unprecedented level of collaboration of its research participants in a focused and coherent programme that significantly reduces the fragmentation of other funding instruments”. The report stresses the key added value of Joint Technology Initiatives being realised on a European scale. The public-private approach is also considered effective in the governance and execution of the programme. The report acknowledges the results on innovative technologies such as laminar wings and contra-rotating open rotor, with significant impact on CO2 emissions reduction. Read more on the detailed evaluation as well as the “top ten” recommendations suggested by the experts here. Commission review states that partnerships in research and innovation boost the economy - News Alert - Research & Innovation - European Commission.

title: MAESTRO project makes small airplanes lighter
text: The MAESTRO Ultra-Compact Reverse Flow Combuster, a project within Clean Sky 2’s Small Air Transport platform, aims to reduce fuel consumption by 15% and NOx emissions by up to 40%, when integrated into next-generation engines. This will be accomplished through the use of Additive Manufacturing and digitisation to result in fewer parts and a lighter engine weight, leading to a more fuel-efficient aircraft. Learn more with this video from Avio Aero on the MAESTRO project.

title: Clean Sky participation in AIDAA Conference in Italy, 18-22 September
text: Clean Sky was the focus of a roundtable at the 24th AIDAA Conference, which took place from 18-22 September in Palermo and Enna, Sicily (Italy). Giuseppe Pagnano, Coordinating Project Officer from Clean Sky, moderated a series of speakers representing key actors in Clean Sky such as SMEs, universities, and research centres. They discussed the value of the public-private partnership model, and evaluated both Clean Sky 1’s and Clean Sky 2’s actual contribution to supporting growth in technological competence and capabilities in SMEs, academia and research centres, as well as the impact on the Italian aviation sector. Suggestions were given for the next Framework Programme and a possible Clean Sky 3. The conference also featured a selection of the best papers, and the Luigi Pascale PhD Student Best Paper Award was given to Zi Wang PhD of the University of Nottingham for her paper on aeroelastic analysis of a wing/propeller configuration of a compound helicopter, referencing the H3 by Airbus Helicopters, with application on Clean Sky 2’s RACER Demonstrator.

title: A step forward for the UltraFan with Power Gearbox milestone
text: The Power Gearbox, a key part of the UltraFan engine which is being developed by Rolls-Royce within Clean Sky 2’s Engines ITD, has been officially announced as the world’s most powerful aerospace gearbox, reaching 70,000 horsepower in testing at Rolls-Royce’s dedicated facility in Dahlewitz, Germany. The original design for the Power Gearbox was completed within Clean Sky, and the associated improvement in efficiency and reduction in weight will allow the UltraFan engine to offer a 25% fuel efficiency improvement over previous Rolls-Royce Trent engines.   Learn more

title: Advance3 in motion
text: Co-funded through the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking providing European Union research funding from the 7th Framework Programme as well as Horizon 2020, and the UK Aerospace Technology Institute (ATI) in association with Innovate UK, Advance3 is the first of Rolls-Royce’s large engine programmes to demonstrate the new Advance core engine for future applications. The engine is now preparing for testing at Rolls-Royce’s facility in Derby, UK. The Advance3 is a hybrid engine with a Trent XWB fan system, a Trent 1000 LP turbine and the brand new Advance core in the middle. The demonstrator will also continue testing a number of key technologies including Ceramic Matrix Composites [CMCs], the new specialist turbine manufacturing method (CastBond™), the lean burn combustion system and a number of 3D printed components. Projects funded through Clean Sky 1 and Clean Sky 2 have brought together a strong community jointly pursuing the technological advances represented in this major demonstrator. In total, 65 participants selected through the Calls for Proposals, including 14 Small and Medium-sized Enterprises and 31 Universities or Research Establishments, have worked to date in a collaborative approach with Rolls-Royce, supported by an EU funding of more than 110M€. In particular, major technology bricks were achieved through the CS1 SAGE (Sustainable and Green Engines) 3 project regarding the Advanced Low Pressure System (ALPS) demonstrator and the SAGE 6 project on the Lean Burn Combustion. Together with earlier and concurrent EU funded projects such as ENOVAL, LEMCOTEC and E-BREAK, the European Union funding for advanced technologies linked to the next generation of large turbofan engines demonstrates the strong shared commitment towards environmentally friendly and economically superior engine technology emerging from the European industry, securing Europe’s lead in this important sector. Learn more about Advance3 on the Rolls-Royce website.

title: First prototypes of Additive Manufacturing technologies for regional aircraft
text: Airbus Defence and Space (CASA) is leading the Clean Sky 2 Regional MultiMission Aircraft concept, integrating technologies dedicated to high versatility missions. The Manufacturing Technology Centre, with the support of ACITURRI Eng., has developed a hinge fitting which has been designed using innovative design techniques and Additive Manufacturing (AM) technology, in order to maximise the benefits in terms of weight and raw material waste reduction. Currently, reductions of up to 40% in weight and 90% in waste reduction are being seen in the first samples when compared to the conventional design. The hinge fitting is a critical part for the Regional Flight Test Bed 2 demonstrator. Click here to read more.

title: Workshop with Member States and Regions
text: The Clean Sky 2 workshop with Member States and Regions dedicated to synergies with ESIF in the field of aviation/aeronautics took place in Brussels on 3 July 2017. Around 50 participants from Member States, Regions, industry, research organisations, clusters, European institutions and other stakeholders attended the workshop and participated in the afternoon’s parallel table discussions.   The workshop aimed to inform national/regional authorities and stakeholders about the challenges and opportunities offered by the synergies between Horizon 2020 and ESIF (European Structural Investment Funds), as presented by speakers from Clean Sky 2 JU, DG RTD, DG REGIO and DG JRC. It also allowed for an exchange of experiences and best practices between the 13 Member States and Regions who have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on synergies with Clean Sky 2 JU, and other Member States/Regions with Smart Specialisation priorities focused on aviation/aeronautics/aerospace or other related areas. During the workshop, some obstacles, barriers and bottlenecks that have been identified so far were discussed, with strategic and effective conclusions being offered.   The speakers highlighted the potential and presented ways to foster synergies with ESIF and other national/regional funds with Clean Sky activities, as well as the perspectives and preliminary results of the MoU cooperations with Member States and Regions and the aspects of the MoU implementation.   All presentations from the workshop are now available on our website.   More information about the synergies with ESIF can be found at this link or you can download our recent published brochure.

title: Andalusia opens a mechanism for funding complementarities with Clean Sky 2 JU
text: The Agency of Innovation and Development of Andalusia (IDEA Agency) officially launched on 17 July 2017 a call for a new ‘Entrepreneurial R&D&I Support Program’ Incentives Scheme addressed to Andalusian companies. The new call includes support scheme for a specific typology of projects, within the ‘Promotion Program for International R&D&I’, which are complementary actions to Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking (under H2020) and other R&D&I programs of Joint Research Area. Within the framework of the Memorandum of Understanding that Andalusia signed with Clean Sky 2, interested Andalusian companies are encouraged to submit under this call complementary proposals that are accompanied by a positive evaluation (above threshold)  and a “synergy label” certification awarded by Clean Sky; a number of synergy labels were already awarded. The stakeholders can also submit proposals that have a positive evaluation (above threshold) by Clean Sky 2 and that were placed by Clean Sky 2 in the reserve list of a call and thus remained not funded. On the latter, IDEA Agency will liaise with Clean Sky 2 on whether these proposals may be considered as complementary and contributing to Clean Sky 2 objectives. At the same time, Andalusian stakeholders are also encouraged to submit proposals under the Calls for Proposals launched by Clean Sky 2 and propose complementary activities via the Part C of the application form since they could now take advantage of funding complementarities between Clean Sky calls and Andalusian public aid instruments. The objectives of this incentive are to increase the competitiveness of companies by generating and incorporating knowledge, technologies and innovations, improving processes and creating technologically advanced products and services with greater added value, as well as to increase the number of participants in international projects integrating them into European collaborative innovation initiatives and taking advantage of the synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), Horizon 2020 and other European programs for the promotion of research and business innovation.   Additional information: • Andalusian Government Official Journal (BOJA): http://juntadeandalucia.es/boja/2017/133/BOJA17-133-00012-12617-01_00117808.pdf http://juntadeandalucia.es/boja/2017/133/BOJA17-133-00012-12628-01_00117815.pdf   • Access to online procedure office of IDEA Agency: https://oficinavirtual.agenciaidea.es/index.do   Learn more about Clean Sky’s work with Member States and Regions here.

title: Clean Sky working together with the Member States and Regions brochure
text: Clean Sky working together with the Member States and Regions brochure is published! The new brochure provides an insight into how Clean Sky develops closer interaction with Member States and Regions and promotes the synergies with European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF) in the field of aviation. title: The launch of the National R&D calls - Synergies with ESIF
text: The Portuguese National Innovation Agency (ANI) announced on 23 February 2017 the launch of the National R&D calls PT2020 for Collaborative R&D projects and Demonstrators and Pilot Lines (individual and collaborative projects). The total budget of these calls is 51,25M€. The collaborative calls will support consortia involving a minimum of 1 company and 1 other entity (either a company or research institution). In the framework of the implementation of the Memorandum in place between CSJU and Portugal on synergies with ESIF, projects that are complementary to Clean Sky 2 may be submitted to these calls. In this context, CSJU and ANI encourages Portuguese beneficiaries in Clean Sky 2 to present proposals which are complementary to their activities in Clean Sky2 or which are aligned and contribute to the Clean Sky 2 objectives.   More information at the following websites: http://ani.pt/candidaturas-abertas-projetos-em-copromocao-e-projetos-demonstradores/ http://ani.pt/incentivos/idt-em-co-promocao/ http://ani.pt/incentivos/demonstradores/

title: Clean Sky 2 Conference in Prague
text: A national conference on Clean Sky 2 took place in Prague on 15 February, organised by the Ministry of Industry and Trade of Czech Republic in cooperation with the key Czech stakeholders participating in Clean Sky 2. Tiit Jürimäe, Interim Executive Director of Clean Sky, provided an overview of the programme following a welcome speech by Deputy Minister Karel Novotný and a presentation by Deputy Minister Tomas Novotný on the synergies with H2020/ESIF within the National Operational Programme for Innovation (OPEIC). Bruno Mastantuono, Clean Sky’s Legal and Strategic Advisor, provided an overview of the calls opportunities launched by CSJU and on the successful level of participation of Czech stakeholders in Clean Sky 2. This was followed by a technical presentation on Small Air Transport by Michel Goulain from Clean Sky. The conference included a round table on synergies with ESIF to make the point on the state of play of implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding on synergies signed by CSJU and the Ministry of Industry in 2016. Bruno Mastantuono and Marcela Příhodová from the Ministry of Industry presented an overview of the joint Action Plan and the national funding instruments under which complementarity activities could be considered for ESIF support. Some key Czech stakeholders in Clean Sky 2 including Evektor (CSJU Leader), Honeywell and GE Aviation Czech (CSJU Core Partners) provided an overview of their activities in Clean Sky 2 and presented some complementary activities areas which could be considered for support under ESIF.  The company ‘Woodcomp Propellers’ presented its experience with the ESIF OPEIC pilot project ‘Argos’ in the area of ENGINES, which received a synergy label from CSJU and was finally awarded an ESIF grant under the national call ‘Aplikace’. Speakers included Joseph Kašpar  (ALV President), Zdeněk Mikulka (Evektor), Rob Levin (GE Aviation Czech), Marcela Sapakova (Honeywell International), Michaela Vlkova (NCP for CZ), Petr Průcha  (La Composite, CSJJ Partner), and Hynek Walmer (Jihostroj, CSJU Partner), as well as other representatives of the Ministry of Industry and Ministry of Research and Innovation. All presentations in EN from the conference can be downloaded from the website of the Ministry of Industry and Trade.

title: Clean Sky at EurActiv conference: ‘Flying into the Future: Innovation in Aviation’
text: Ron van Manen, Clean Sky 2 Programme Manager, spoke at a conference organised by EurActiv in Brussels titled ‘Flying into the Future: Innovation in Aviation’. The event discussed the ever-growing pressure on the aviation sector to deliver innovative and sustainable solutions, due to the rise in air traffic, and highlighted the industry’s focus on greener technology for aviation, while maintaining European competitiveness in the sector. Other speakers included MEP Jacqueline Foster (Vice-Chair of the Sky and Space Intergroup), Peter Vis (Advisor to the Director General, DG Move), Riccardo Procacci (CEO, Avio), Brian Moran (Vice President of Government Affairs for Boeing Europe, Boeing) and Bill Hemmings (Director Aviation and Shipping, Transport & Environment). All information about the event can be found here.

Safran’s Counter Rotating Open Rotor will be put to test, while the Airbus BLADE demonstrator aircraft will fly in 2017. Both are listed in Aviation Week’s article on technologies to watch in 2017: http://aviationweek.com/awin-only/commercial-aviation-technologies-will-evolve-2017

title: Clean Sky at EU Agencies Forum
text: Clean Sky has attended the EU Agencies Forum at the European Parliament in Brussels on 6-7 December. The event focused on how the EU Agencies and Joint Undertakings contribute to the implementation of EU policies for the benefit of citizens and industries.   The first day of the conference featured panel sessions on the contributions of EU Agencies and Joint Undertakings to four EU policy priorities: ‘Boosting Jobs, Growth and Investment’, ‘Citizens First’, ‘Justice and Home Affairs’, and ‘Innovative Europe’. The day started with keynote speeches from Martin Schulz (President of the European Parliament), Kristalina Georgieva (Vice-President of the European Commission), Tibor Stelbaczky (Deputy Permanent Representative, Permanent Representation of Hungary to the EU) and Sandra Lagumina (Executive Vice-President, ENGIE Group). Other speakers throughout the day included representatives from the European Commission and the European Parliament, as well as EU agencies and industry.   The event concluded in the morning of Wednesday 7 December with a summary of the sessions of the previous day, followed by a panel titled ‘EU Agencies – the way forward’, with speakers including Herman Van Rompuy, President of the European Policy Center (also former Prime Minister of Belgium and the first President of the European Council) and MEPs Inés Ayala Sender and Siegfried Muresan, among others.   See how EU Agencies are working for you

title: 2nd EU Aeronautics Conference
text: Clean Sky took part in the 2nd EU Aeronautics Conference at the European Parliament in Brussels, an opportunity to gather high-level EU and national decision makers as well as the aeronautics industry leaders and representatives of R&D centres and users, to discuss in Q&A sessions of how to preserve this European success story and how to ensure its long term sustainability. The conference began with opening remarks from Violeta Bulc who called on the industry to bring innovative solutions to improve the environment. Tiit Jürimäe, interim Executive Director at Clean Sky highlighted how the Joint Undertaking is a strategic partnership in this iconic sector. A host of critical issues were also debated in light of the “Aviation Strategy for Europe” adopted in December 2015 by the European Commission, the Union’s “Digital Agenda” as well as perspectives on both Clean Sky and SESAR programmes and the current mid-term review of the European R&D and innovation programme, Horizon 2020.

title: The Clean Sky Awards is now open for young scientists to apply
text: The Clean Sky Joint Undertaking is pleased to announce the second edition of the Award for distinguished young scientists who have recently completed a PhD thesis in the field of Aeronautics that falls within the scope of a Clean Sky project. The Award is now open for potential candidates to submit an application, which must have been approved at a University or a Research Organisation in Europe (including Associated Countries according to H2020) before December 31, 2016. The closing date for applications is January 15, 2017 at 5:00pm (Brussels time). The Clean Sky PhD-Award Committee will select three awardees and communicate the decision by February 22, 2017 followed by the Award Presentation at the Clean Sky Forum in Brussels on March 21-22, 2017. Applications should be submitted electronically to phd-award-2017@cleansky.eu. For more information please see: http://cleansky.eu/clean-sky-best-phd-award-2017 We look forward to receiving your submissions.

title: Clean Sky attends the Innovation Sessions at the European Economic and Social Committee
text: Clean Sky attended the Innovation Sessions held at the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) in Brussels on Monday, organised by the Portuguese Trade & Investment Agency (AICEP), in cooperation with the Confederation of Portuguese Business (CIP), the Portuguese Agency for Innovation (ANI) and Eupportunity. The focus of the one-day event was to bring together European stakeholders from industry and research within the aeronautical and energy sectors. As part of this event, Tiit Jürimäe, interim Executive Director at Clean Sky outlined the goals of the public-private partnership and how aeronautics is a key innovation driver in the European economy: both to retain the sectors competitive edge but also the need to enhance the environmental performance of aircraft and lessen noise pollution. In addition, representatives also discussed the priorities and the challenges facing aeronautics, as well as a specific focus on the Portuguese aeronautical cluster and a keynote address from Mr. Carlos Moedas, the European Commissioner for Research, Science and Innovation.

title: Memorandum of Understanding signed with Portugal
text: Clean Sky signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on 27 October with Portugal, at national level. The ceremony took place in Lisbon during AED Days 2016, a conference for the European aeronautics, space and defence sectors. The Presidents of ANI (Agência Nacional de Inovação, S.A) and FCT (Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia, I.P) represented Portugal, while Tiit Jürimäe, as Interim Executive Director, signed for Clean Sky. The ceremony also included speeches from two Portuguese Secretaries of State: Maria Fernanda Rollo (Secretary of State of Science, Technology and Higher Education), and Marcos Perestrello (Secretary of State of National Defence). The aim of this MoU is to build a strategic cooperation to explore synergies and complementarities (cooperative research and pilot demonstrations of common interest) between the Portuguese national programme PT2020 and Clean Sky. A working group will be established to ensure its implementation. This is the 12th Memorandum of Understanding to be signed by Clean Sky as part of its pilot phase on fostering synergies with ESIF. Read more about Clean Sky’s synergies with structural funds here.

title: Eric Dautriat wins CEAS Gold Award 2017
text: Eric Dautriat, Clean Sky’s Executive Director, has won the CEAS (Council of European Aerospace Societies) Gold Award for 2017.   He was selected by the CEAS Awards Committee in June 2016. CEAS said: “Eric Dautriat has contributed in an exemplary, outstanding way to the French space community and to the European aeronautics technology development and demonstration, essential for the progress of the environmental sustainability and competitiveness of the European aeronautical industry.”    Congratulations to Eric Dautriat on this achievement!   Read more on the CEAS website

title: Clean Sky at INNOVAIR National aeronautics in Sweden
text: The Swedish Society of Aeronautics and Astronautics (FTF) in cooperation with the Strategic Innovation Programme Aeronautics (Innovair) held the Swedish Aerospace Technology Congress, the ninth triennial congress arranged by FTF on the 11-12 October in Solna (Stockholm), Sweden. The Congress has become a well established forum for Swedish aerospace technology, with the aim of promoting research as well as technical and industrial development in the aerospace sector and also to create stimuli for higher education in aerospace. As part of the Congress programme, Ron van Manen (Clean Sky 2 Programme Manager) presented an overview of Clean Sky 2: the set-up of the programme and participation, sketching out the progress to date, addressing the H2020 challenges as well ESIF – the regional dimension exemplified by the case of two Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) with the South East (Östergötland) and West (Västergötland) regions in Sweden.   View the presentation here

title: Eric Dautriat steps down as Clean Sky Executive Director
text: Eric Dautriat will depart his role as Executive Director of Clean Sky Joint Undertaking (CSJU) from 15th September, having completed his second term, and the last possible according to the Clean Sky EU Regulation. After 7 years at the helm, Eric has been a key part of CSJU from its inception and has overseen the completion of several innovative technology Demonstrators within the strategic research partnership between the European Commission and the aeronautical industry. Clean Sky Joint Undertaking would like to thank Eric for his extraordinary contribution over the years and wish him every success in his future endeavours. As the recruitment of Eric’s successor is still ongoing, from 16th September CSJU will be piloted ad interim by Tiit Jurimae, temporarily seconded to the Joint Undertaking by the European Commission. Tiit Jurimae brings with him many years of experience from the European Commission in the area of Research, Science and Innovation. A welcomed addition to the team who will remain in post until a permanent Executive Director is appointed, taking over at an exciting time as Clean Sky 1 transitions into its landing phase with several large demonstrators to be completed, and as Clean Sky 2 takes off and begins its steady climb. Clean Sky looks forward to welcoming Tiit Jurimae in the coming weeks, to continue CSJU’s work in earnest.

title: Register now: Greener Aviation 2016
text: Registration is now open for the Greener Aviation: Clean Sky breakthroughs and worldwide status conference. Organised by the French Aeronautics and Astronautics Society (3AF), with the support of Clean Sky Joint Undertaking (CSJU) and the Council of European Aeronautical Societies (CEAS), Greener Aviation 2016 will be held in Brussels (Belgium) on 11-13 October 2016. By welcoming contributions from worldwide projects and programmes, the conference will give a unique overview of the worldwide research efforts for improving the impact of aviation on climate change issues and to comply with new market standards. Greener Aviation 2016 will welcome 160 speakers from the EU as well as the United States, Japan, Brazil, Russia and Canada. This is a unique opportunity to meet and network with worldwide aviation leaders and showcase the latest innovations in structures, propulsion, aircraft configurations, materials, noise reduction, alternative fuels and new ATM systems.   Programme      Registration

title: Romanian synergy call launched
text: The National Authority for Scientific Research and Innovation of Romania (ANCSI) has recently launched a dedicated call for supporting synergies between ESIF and Horizon 2020 and other international R&D programmes, including Clean Sky 2 (type of projects “COMPLEMENT”).   The call is launched under the Competitiveness Operational Programme 2014-2020, Priority Axis 1. (http://www.poc.research.ro/actiuni-1-1-3*).   A higher interest and motivation of research-performing organisations and industry from Romania in participation to different projects at European level, including Clean Sky 2 projects, is expected.   Hence, based on the Memorandum of Understanding between ANCSI and Clean Sky 2 JU, signed in July 2015 with the aim of amplifying the scope and the impact of Clean Sky 2 projects by developing a close interaction with structural funds, applicants from Romania are encouraged to propose complementary activities eligible for support through ESIF that are in synergy with Clean Sky 2 and/or contribute to the objectives of the Clean Sky 2 Programme.   Satisfaction was expressed on both sides by Clean Sky 2 JU and ANCSI with the launch of this national call which follows a set of exchanges and consultations between the two Organisations related to the implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding. * English version will be available soon

title: Clean Sky/Airbus Flight Lab takes off
text: The first flight of the Airbus Flight Lab (A320 MSN1) took place on 3 June. The aircraft features a number of innovative electrical technologies developed within Clean Sky’s SGO Systems for Green operations (SGO) platform, including the Electrical Environmental Control System (Liebherr), Electrical Power Centre (Airbus/Thales), Scoop Inlet with acoustic and anti-ice systems (Sandit consortium/Airbus) and the Primary In-Flight Icing Detection System (Zodiac).   The flight test campaign will evaluate robustness, performance and integration of these technologies over the aircraft operating envelope. Preliminary results are promising.

title: Clean Sky at ILA Berlin
text: Clean Sky featured at ILA Berlin today with a conference titled ‘The Science powering Clean Sky’. Around 100 people attended the event, which also included the inaugural ‘Clean Sky Best PhD Awards’. The conference opened with a welcome address from Clara de la Torre, Director of DG Research and Innovation of the European Commission. The focus was on science and research as essential parts of Clean Sky’s activities and highlighted how universities and research organisations help develop technologies from ideas to reality.  Other speakers were Ric Parker, Chair of the Clean Sky Governing Board; Peter Hecker, Chair of Clean Sky Scientific Committee; Hannes Krieg, Project Manager, University of Stuttgart; Ron van Manen, Clean Sky 2 Programme Manager; Rolf Henke, ACARE Chairman, Member of the Executive Board for aeronautics research, DLR; and Jean-Francois Brouckaert, Clean Sky Project Officer. The conference finished with a celebration of outstanding young researchers in the Best Clean Sky PhD Award ceremony. First prize was awarded to Tao Yang (University of Nottingham) for his thesis ‘Development of Dynamic Phasors for the Modelling of Aircraft Electrical Power Systems’. Silver and bronze went respectively to Beniamino Guida (Second University of Naples) and Simon Colliss (University of Cambridge). Francesco Grasso, Chair of Aero Technical Institute, CNAM, then rounded up the awards with a presentation highlighting the importance of young researchers to the future of Clean Sky and aeronautics in general.

title: Clean Sky signs Memorandum of Understanding with Zuid-Holland
text: Clean Sky signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Zuid-Holland region of The Netherlands yesterday. The ceremony took place during the Innovation Award Drechtsteden event in Dordrecht, The Netherlands. The MoU was signed by the Commissioner of the King Jaap Smit, representing the Province of Zuid-Holland, and Elizabeth Gavin, representing the Clean Sky Joint Undertaking. The signed MoU aims to foster ties between the region and the Clean Sky 2 programme: increased investment in aeronautics in the region could lead to the creation of 2000 jobs. Read the full press release here

title: Clean Sky 2 high-speed compound helicopter demonstrator making good progress
text: It has been an exciting year so far for Airbus Helicopter’s high-speed compound helicopter demonstrator ‘LifeRCraft’, which is being developed under Clean Sky 2. The pre-design phase, involving all core partners, has now been completed, and recently a mock-up of the breakthrough airframe design was tested in a windtunnel at an Airbus facility. These tests confirmed the viability of the chosen design in terms of efficiency, sustainability and performance, and a preliminary review of the overall design is expected to take place before the end of 2016. The ultimate objective of the demonstrator is to meet future requirements for increased speed, better cost-efficiency, and reductions of emissions and noise footprint. Flight tests are expected to start in 2019. “We are honoured to be carrying out this project on behalf of the Clean Sky Joint Undertaking and the large number of European companies who are taking part in the development. Our ambition is to become the benchmark of the rotorcraft industry, and as such we are willing to drive a bold vision for the future of helicopter transportation,” said Jean-Brice Dumont, Airbus Helicopters Chief Technical Officer. He underlined the importance of the demonstrator in finding the best balance between cost-efficiency, sustainability and mission performance, and the aim to pave the way for future applications such as emergency missions by breaking the cost barrier usually associated with increased speed and range. Ron van Manen, Clean Sky 2 Programme Manager, highlighted that “The LifeRCraft Demonstrator project in Clean Sky 2 will pull together capabilities from across the European Research Area, addressing technology gaps in systems, structures and overall design and demonstrating the viability of a compound rotorcraft design that can bring a fundamentally new combination of payload / range / speed to the aviation market. In particular where a rapid response or a key range requirement exists (such as in disaster relief, medical evacuation or search & rescue) this aircraft concept can bring important benefits to the public and open new market opportunities that will strengthen Europe’s already formidable competitive position in the vertical life aviation sector.”   Read the full press release here

title: Clean Sky signs Memorandum of Understanding with Castilla-La Mancha
text: Clean Sky signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) today with the Spanish region of Castilla-La Mancha. Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, signed alongside Patricia Franco Jiménez, the Regional Counsellor for Economy, Industry and Employment, at the ceremony in Toledo.   The MoU will last for four years, including a pilot phase from 2016-2017. The objective is to establish a cooperation on synergies with ESIF (European Structural and Investment Funds) managed by Castilla-La Mancha, which has indicated aeronautics among its Regional Smart Specialisations priorities. In terms of implementation, the aim is to identify complementary research and innovation activities linked to the Clean Sky 2 programme and fit for a Clean Sky synergy label, for possible ESIF financing. The signing was followed by a workshop with the Regional Aero Cluster and the Spanish CDTI (Centre for the Development of Industrial Technology), as well as representatives from Airbus (a Clean Sky Leader) and Aernnova (a Core Partner performing Clean Sky 2 activities in Castilla-La Mancha). This is the 10th MoU signed by Clean Sky, and the third in Spain. Read more about Clean Sky’s synergies with structural funds here.

text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, has met a number of MEPs at the European Parliament in Brussels this week. A meeting yesterday with German MEP Michael Cramer, Chair of the European Parliament’s Transport Committee, followed discussions on Tuesday with Finnish MEP Henna Virkkunen and Bulgarian MEP Vladimir Urutchev, both members of the Parliament’s Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). title: Clean Sky socio-economic study - powering a stronger Europe
text: The aeronautics industry is a constantly-growing sector of excellence in Europe, with jobs amounting to around 534 000, global demand increasing by more than 4% per annum, and an estimated need for 40 000 new aircraft over the next 20 years. Although this is a huge opportunity for the European economy, it also creates environmental obligations for manufacturers and airlines and triggers the appearance of new competitors from emerging countries. Therefore it is all the more necessary for the European industry to keep its competitive edge through innovation. This is where Clean Sky comes in. By fostering and coordinating research and innovation, innovative technologies can be developed and integrated into full-scale demonstrators in order to reach a high readiness level for future implementation into new products. The socio-economic impact of the Clean Sky initiative is measured also through the acceleration it provides to the time to market of new products stemming from its successful technical activities and the consequent fall-out on the number of production jobs it creates. Clean Sky 1 started in 2008 and counts over 600 participating entities from 24 countries, including SMEs, research centres and academia. With one year still to go, Clean Sky is already delivering demonstrators resulting in significant reductions in CO2, gas emissions and noise levels with clear socio-economic benefits for society at large. It is a mark of Clean Sky 1’s success that a follow-up, Clean Sky 2, was launched in 2014. It has already had 4 Calls for Proposals and recruited some 200 participating entities.

title: Ric Parker at European Parliament’s Sky and Space Intergroup debate on innovation for sustainable aviation
text: Ric Parker, Chair of the Clean Sky Governing Board and Director of Research and Technology at Rolls-Royce, spoke today at a debate organised by the European Parliament’s Sky and Space Intergroup and ASD (AeroSpace and Defence Industries Association of Europe), on the subject of innovation for a sustainable aviation. The event was chaired by MEP Marian-Jean Marinescu and attended by several other MEPs including Inés Ayala Sender, Paul Rübig, Gesine Meissner, Antonio Tajani, Deirdre Clune, and Franck Proust. Ric Parker addressed the environmental challenges ahead and noted the industry’s voluntary commitment to reducing CO2 emissions and noise. He highlighted that Clean Sky is already demonstrating the next generation of sustainable technologies and that, in doing so, the programme has built up a solid and innovative network of SMEs, universities and research centres. To read more about Clean Sky’s success stories and fact & figures, click here. Read Ric Parker’s speech from the event here

title: Public Hearing at the European Parliament on Synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds
text: Eric Dautriat spoke at a public hearing at the European Parliament organised by the EPP party on Horizon 2020 and other European Innovation Funds. The event was hosted by MEP Lambert van Nistelrooij. Other speakers from the European Parliament and the Commission were MEP Maria Spyraki, MEP Jan Olbrycht, MEP Ivana Maletic and Katja Reppel. Clean Sky has launched an action plan on synergies and is developing close interactions with interested Member States and Regions in Europe. The aim is to strengthen the R&I innovation capacity and the European dimension of the Regions in aeronautics, to identify areas of technical cooperation which could complement the Programme and support its overall objectives.

title: Clean Sky meets MEPs Vicky Ford and Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy
text: Clean Sky’s Executive Director Eric Dautriat held meetings today with British MEP Vicky Ford, Chair of the European Parliament’s IMCO committee, and French MEP Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy, member of the Transport committee. In both meetings, Eric Dautriat explained the environmental, competitiveness and mobility issues that Clean Sky aims to address and asked for support to encourage wide participation from SMEs, research centres and universities in their regions in Clean Sky 2’s calls.

title: Small Air Transport workshop in Poland
text: A two-day workshop on Small Air Transport (SAT) is being held this week by Clean Sky and the Institute of Aviation, Warsaw. The event takes place in Poland at the Institute of Aviation (ILOT), and brings together nearly 100 participants. The workshop was opened on 4 February by Witold Wiśniowski (Director, ILOT) and Eric Dautriat (Clean Sky’s Executive Director), and includes several presentations from Clean Sky and Institute of Aviation representatives as well as private organisations such as Piaggio, Evektor, EASA and Eurocontrol. The event continues on 5 February with two technical sessions moderated by Clean Sky, which are followed by presentations from Airbus, DLR, Pipistrel and FCH JU.   Check out the video from the event:

title: Clean Sky signs Memorandum of Understanding with Swedish Regions
text: On 17 February 2016, Clean Sky signed two Memoranda of Understanding (MoU) with the Swedish regions of Västra Götaland and Östergötland– the first MoUs of their kind to be signed with Sweden. The ceremony took place in Stockholm at Vinnova (Sweden’s national innovation agency), and was attended by representatives of the regions and by Clean Sky Executive Director Eric Dautriat. The MoU will mutually benefit both Clean Sky and the Swedish regions: the regions will be able to synchronise applications from European Structural Fund calls and Clean Sky calls, giving applicants (particularly SMEs) better opportunities to address common innovation objectives (competitiveness and societal challenges) as set out in the Swedish aerospace research and innovation agenda Flyg; and for Clean Sky, the MoU means gaining direct access to a network of highly-qualified sub-tier suppliers, boosting competitiveness at European level. Moreover, building up this synergy at EU level with Clean Sky will also lead the Regions and the State to deepen their own internal cooperation.

title: Eric Dautriat discusses research opportunities at EASN event
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, spoke this afternoon at an event hosted by EASN (The European Aeronautics Science Network) in Brussels. The main theme of the event was the importance of academic research in aviation and how it can be maintained and encouraged. Eric Dautriat’s presentation was titled “Academia in industry-led research”, and insisted on the strong role that Academia already play in Clean Sky, but also encouraged them to be pro-active in Clean Sky 2 and propose breakthrough activities fitting the objectives of the programme. Other speakers at the event were Prof. Dieter Schmitt (Aeronautical Consultant, EASN honorary member), Dr Helge Pfeiffer (General Secretary EASN, KU Leuven / University of Leuven), Prof. Dr.-Ing Joachim Szodruch (Board Member German Aerospace Centre, ret.) and Prof.dr.ir. Leo Veldhuis (TU Delft / Delft University of Technology).

title: Clean Sky meets with MEP Kyllönen
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, today met MEP Merja Kyllönen, a member of the Transport Committee of the European Parliament. They discussed the environmental challenges associated with aviation and Clean Sky’s main objectives, which are to reduce CO2 emissions and noise levels by up to 50% by 2020, compared with the levels in the year 2000. They also spoke about the achievements made by Clean Sky so far in reaching these targets.

title: Clean Sky Best PhD Award in Aeronautics
text: Clean Sky award for best PhD Thesis in applied sciences and engineering for aeronautics.   The Clean Sky European Joint Undertaking is pleased to announce the first edition of the Award to distinguish young scientists who have recently completed a PhD thesis in the field of Aeronautics within a Clean Sky Project.   The Meaning of the Award is to highlight outstanding achievements of three young persons at the start of their scientific careers. The Content of the Award is an Award, including an Award Certificate, plus the cost for the attendance of the Award Ceremony.  The Application: Every person who has presented a thesis within the field of Aeronautics, within the frame of a Clean Sky project qualifies for the Award and can submit an application. The PhD thesis must have been approved at a University or a Research Organisation in Europe (including Associated Countries according to H2020) before December 31, 2015.  Applications can be filed until March 31st, 2016, 5:00 PM. The Award Ceremony to give the best PhD Award will take place on 1st June 2016, at the Clean Sky Conference at ILA Berlin.   Read the complete PhD Award Regulation Apply here: download PhD Research Summary template   Please contact Phd-award-2016@cleansky.eu in case of further questions.

title: Clean Sky and SESAR strengthen coordination for innovative aviation
text: Clean Sky and SESAR Joint Undertakings (JUs) have signed yesterday a Memorandum of Cooperation (MoC) in order to foster closer links between the two research and innovation (R&I) programmes. The purpose of the MoC is to establish a cooperative framework between the two JUs, contributing to the sustainable development of the European air transport system.   Read the full press release here

title: Clean Sky at the European Parliament
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, today held meetings with representatives of the Transport Committee at the European Parliament: Keith Taylor (Greens) and Wim van de Camp (EPP). At both meetings, environmental, competitiveness and mobility issues were discussed, as well as how to keep Europe and its regions at the forefront of innovation. Eric Dautriat also elaborated on the synergies between Clean Sky and the EU Structural Funds that have already led to agreements being signed with six European regions.

title: European public-private partnerships (PPPs) join forces at Innovation Week at the European Parliament
text: Innovative European public-private partnerships (PPPs) are now starting to deliver socio-economic impacts in key industrial sectors, including aviation, electronic components & systems, health, and fuel cells and hydrogen for transport & energy solutions. The PPPs, all partnerships between the European Union, industries and (in some cases) Member States, are presenting their activities and successes in the European Parliament during the European Innovation Summit. The results demonstrate the added value of the PPP model and explain why two new PPPs have been set up more recently in the fields of bio-based products and rail. Read the full press release here

title: Clean Sky 2 Systems Integrated Technology Demonstration Launch Review
text: Liebherr-Aerospace Lindenberg GmbH, Lindenberg (Germany) hosted the Clean Sky 2 Integrated Technology Demonstration (ITD) Systems Launch Review on November 19th and 20th, 2015, in Weiler (Germany). Technical representatives of more than 30 companies and research institutes, together with technical independent experts mandated by the European Commission and the Clean Sky Joint Undertaking (www.cleansky.eu), came together in order to set the course for long term activities related to the major system demonstrators. The leaders of Clean Sky 2 presented detailed planning of activities including the involvement of additional members and future members or external contributors. The reviewers evaluated the coherence of each project with the global framework and the expected contributions to the High Level Objectives of Clean Sky 2. The main objective is to ensure a solid collaborative program and a consequent involvement of all partners. As one of the coordinators of the ITD, Liebherr-Aerospace will interface with the European funding authorities and represent the industry consortium within the program. Thanks to major technology innovations, Liebherr-Aerospace and the whole consortium are reducing the environmental impact of future aircraft generations in terms of both noise and emissions, and increase at the same time the competitiveness of the European supply chain.

title: Eric Dautriat speaks at 7th European Innovation Summit
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, joined the other Joint Undertakings (JUs) at the European Parliament’s Innovation Summit in a panel titled ‘The Socio-economic impact of the Joint Undertakings’. In his presentation, Eric Dautriat discussed the growth of the aerospace industry and the environmental challenges associated with this, and therefore the importance of Clean Sky. He also focused on the wide range of participants in Clean Sky, including industrial leaders, universities, research centres and European SMEs. He finished by saying that Clean Sky is already displaying visible results: in some cases, the developed technologies – for instance, new engines, structures, aerodynamics, on-board energy systems and avionics – are already being integrated into products. The other speakers in the panel were Philippe Mengal (Executive Director of BBI JU), Bert de Colvenaer (Executive Director of FCH JU), Yves Gigase (Acting Executive Director, ECSEL), Pierre Meulien (Executive Director of IMI) and Michael Standar (Chief Strategy & External Affairs, SESAR JU). The panel was hosted by MEP Lambert van Nistelrooij.

title: Eric Dautriat at 23rd AIDAA Conference, Turin
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, spoke yesterday at the 23rd AIDAA (Italian Association of Aeronautics and Astronautics) Conference in Turin, Italy. In his plenary talk, he discussed ‘Clean Sky and the Aeronautical Research Eco-system’, including the various green technologies that are under development within the Clean Sky programmes. Clean Sky was also the focus of a Round Table discussion the previous day. The conference lasted three days and was attended by researchers and professionals in the fields of aerospace sciences and engineering. The objective was to “promote a significant exchange of scientific information in the Italian and international aerospace community.”

title: Eric Dautriat speaks at European Parliament’s TRAN Committee hearing
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, spoke today at a hearing of the European Parliament’s Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN). The hearing focused on ‘Transport’s contribution to the achievement of climate and energy objectives’. In his speech, Eric Dautriat reported progress on the green technologies that are under development within the Clean Sky programme, and highlighted the ultimate Clean Sky goals of reducing CO2 emissions and noise levels. Other participants in the event were Claus Seibt (project coordinator in the Research Group Energy, Transport and Climate Policy, Wuppertal Institute for Climate, Environment and Energy), Hans Bruyninckx (Executive Director, European Environment Agency), Rolf Diemer (Head of Unit MOVE A3, Economic analysis, Impact assessment, Climate change & Evaluation, European Commission), Erik Jonnaert (General Secretary, European Automobile Manufacturers’ Association) and Edmund Hughes (Head, Air Pollution and Energy Efficiency, International Maritime Organization).

title: Clean Sky Sustainable and Green Engines (SAGE 4) / MTU: The Geared Turbofan engine demonstrator
text: A milestone was reached today by Clean Sky’s SAGE programme with the demonstration of MTU’s geared turbofan engine in Munich. The event was attended by a number of guests including Bruno Stoufflet, Vice Chair of the Clean Sky Governing Board, and Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, as well as European politicians, partner companies, research institutes and universities. The ultimate goal of the demonstrator is to significantly reduce CO2 emissions and noise levels. It is anticipated that fuel consumption and CO2 emissions could be reduced by up to 15% and perceived noise levels by 50%, in comparison with turbofan engines currently in use. These reductions are in line with Clean Sky’s commitment to reaching the targets set out by ACARE for the year 2020, which include a 50% reduction of CO2 emissions through drastic reduction of fuel consumption, an 80% reduction of NOx (nitrogen oxide) emissions, and a 50% reduction of external noise (compared to levels in 2000). Eric Dautriat said: “This MTU-led project in the Sustainable and Green Engines platform is a very good example of how a recent engine concept, here the geared turbofan, may still be improved through the implementation of a series of new technologies. This will be continued in Clean Sky 2 through another set of improvements. The external, overall shape of the engine may remain the same, but at the end of the day, you have brand new pieces of hardware inside, with benefits for both the environment and competitiveness.” According to MTU: “Although today’s engines achieve extremely high efficiencies each additional tenth of a percent makes a whole lot of a difference, helping cut down on fuel burn and hence reduce CO2 emissions.”   Read the press release here

title: First flight test of the high-compression engine demonstrator aircraft
text: Airbus Helicopters has successfully completed the first flight test of the high-compression engine demonstrator aircraft on Friday, November 6th, at Marignane Airport. The development and flight test of this new technology demonstrator is part of the European Clean Sky initiative’s Green Rotorcraft Integrated Technology Demonstrator (ITD) program, with support for these flight tests provided by the consortium of TEOS Powertrain Engineering and Austro Engine GmbH.

title: Clean Sky signs Memorandum of Understanding with Campania Region, Italy
text: On October 6th 2015, the Executive Director of Clean Sky Eric Dautriat signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Vincenzo de Luca, President of the Campania Region of Italy. The agreement aims to promote synergy between European Union-financed research and innovation projects and the Campania Region. The next step is to appoint a liaison committee, made up of two members each from Clean Sky and the Campania Region, within the next 60 days. This committee will take care of the promotion and management of collaborative activities and will also define the implementation protocols. Vincenzo de Luca said: “The aerospace industry is one of the core strategic investments of Campania. Our region boasts pre-existing industrial scientific research centres, such as to enable the realisation and consolidation of a centre of aerospace development: from research to testing of materials, from industrial production to marketing. We will use European funds in the direction of research, development, strategic investments and the fragmentation of spending.” He added: “The collaboration with Clean Sky is a great support for us both…This important project will enable the Campania Region to apply for accreditation on the European stage. The signing of this protocol is a source of great satisfaction. I am convinced that we will do an excellent job.” Eric Dautriat was also happy with the signing. He said: “I am very pleased to be here to celebrate this important event in the headquarters of the Campania Region - a Region active in the search for technological innovations in the aerospace industry. Clean Sky is ready to make available to them our extraordinary wealth of skills and knowledge in order to promote and support research and innovation in a crucial field for development.”

title: Eric Dautriat at the 1st EU Aeronautics Conference
text: Eric Dautriat, Executive Director of Clean Sky, participated today in the 1st EU Aeronautics Conference, held in Brussels and organised by the European Parliament’s Sky and Space Intergroup together with Business Bridge Europe. The title of the conference was: ‘What EU Strategy for the Competitiveness of the European Aeronautics Industry in a Changing World?’ It aimed to discuss a number of issues concerning the European aeronautics industry, such as the competition from emerging markets like China and Brazil, and the industrial challenges facing the sector coupled with an increasing international demand. However, the conference also had a dedicated session to celebrate the contribution of the aeronautics industry to competitiveness, growth and jobs in the EU. Eric Dautriat joined the panel for the session titled ‘How can the EU support the European aeronautics industry?’, alongside MEPs including Jacqueline Foster and Franck Proust (Vice Chairs of the Sky and Space Intergroup), as well as leading figures from the European Commission and the private sector. The focus here was the EU’s role, both current and future, in supporting investment and growth in the aeronautics industry. The one-day event was opened by a range of speakers including Violeta Bulc (Commissioner for Transport), MEP Antonio Tajani (Vice-President, European Parliament), MEP Jerzy Buzek (Chair, European Parliament ITRE Committee), Mauro Moretti (President of ASD - CEO, Finmeccanica) and Tom Enders (CEO, Airbus Group). It closed with a speech by MEP Monika Hohlmeier, Chair of the Sky and Space Intergroup.
